description:
A fun spot for a good meal!

I came for dinner and was sad to see that they stop serving Cuban sandwiches after 7pm. Fortunately, we were well fed with empanadas, mofongo, and lechon. There isn't a ton of Caribbean food in the area as far as I know, so this was a good opportunity to order something a little different.

There's no liquor here, but the sangria is tasty. I'd come back for a casual dinner when I don't have a reservation and don't feel like waiting in line. The service was also very good.
author: Sara M.

description:
I was on the hunt for some good Puerto Rican food in SF and was excited to try this place out. I've had plenty of mofongo in my life and this is definitely one of the better ones! The sauce was so tasty and good and full of flavor with some nice garlic and sazón. The mofongo itself was excellent, not dry at all and the pork that came with it was very well flavored. 

I also ordered the habichuelas (red beans) and arroz con gandules as my sides and this was enough for two people. Both of these sides were really tasty but the arroz con gandules was definitely the highlight. 

Picking the dessert at the end was a very hard choice but I ended up going with the tres leches and was very happy. It was a big portion and really nice and sweet and just everything you'd want from tres leches. Put waiter was super nice and patient, especially since we were being indecisive about a lot of our order. 

Will 100% be coming back to try the Vaca Frita and a few of the other items on the menu. Stop by if you are in the area and make a trip there if you're not!
author: Valeria S.

description:
I love El Nuevo Frutilandia. I've been coming here for years, especially for family celebrations.

Let's me just say, my father hates eating out and is very particular of where we go if we do eat out, but yet this is one of the few places he loves coming to. 

The food is delicious and better than the few places around for Puerto Rican / Cuban food in the city. The ceviche, tostones, and mofongo are some of my favorite dishes along with their dessert empanadas. 

The management is very nice and beyond accommodating. And unlike other reviews have mentioned, I've never had an issue with the food quality, wait time, or service regardless of how slow or busy they are.

I will continue coming here and getting my Puerto Rican/Cuban food fix as long as I can.
author: Nancy L.

description:
My boyfriend and I passed by this restaurant a few months ago and we FINALLY got the chance to try it. We were so excited and the location is beautiful, right in the heart of Mission District.

We started out with chicken and picadillo empanadas with a side of tostones. That already set the bar high for our entrees, it was so delicious! Filled with flavor and the meats were cooked so well. The empanadas were both crispy and golden, yum.

Our entrees came, he got the ropa vieja and I got the Chile relleno with chicken. They both came with sides of white rice and taro chips. The white rice had a nice kick of flavor, it was a perfect side and so were the chips. The whole meal evened each other out. Along with the great food was friendly smiles of our servers. they were all so kind to us!! Thank you very much for a delicious meal, we look forward to coming back.
author: Vanessa D.

description: Who knew I could lick a whole plate clean. The Ropa veija  was almost as good as abuelitas!
author: Meghan O.

description:
Second time here and the food was Amazing! 
From the pork mofongo, ceviche, and beef& chicken empanadas! 

Service was pretty slow but I understand there was one server on one of the hottest days of summer who ran out of ice.

Food came out fast and it was delicious! I also enjoyed the white wine guava sangria!
author: Brittany C.

description: My absolute very spot in the mission. I'd go here everyday instead of cooking if I could. My family came to visit from New York and I took them here. They begged to go back every night. Any time I have people in town i take them here. The owner and the waitress Katy are the best!
author: Brandon D.

description:
Food was excelent and the servers were super friendly. I would definitely recommend this restaurant.
This was one of my first times tasting Cuban/Puerto Rican food and I was not disappointed. Me and my party were celebrating my cousin's birthday and although it was super short notice, the owner was kind enough to give cousin a slice of their delicious tres leches cake. Me and my party will definetly return and share this amazing place with our friends.
author: Stephanie R.

description:
In reading some past reviews my fellow yelpers hit the nail on the head. The food is good, the server / management is suspect to some criticism. 
We ordered the TOSTONES CON MOJO which were tasty. The 
MOFONGO with shrimp was a bit over priced for the amount of shrimp given. 2 whole shrimp with a small amount of chopped up shrimp.The POLLO A LA ESPAÑOLA had  a nice  house Caribbean butternut carrot spiced sauce. The white chicken was a little dry of the sauce saved the day. The LECHON HORNEADO was a nice  dish with good amount of pork. Both main courses came with Puerto Rican rice and black beans.
To begin our meal our server took our order and just left the menu on the table which I though was odd. The sever came back and told us one of our appetizers was sold out but was not taken off our bill . Our food was given to us without plates We asked for  some and was given 2 small appetizer plates for the main courses. 
Finally right before we were about to finish our meal the manager came over and said "cash only". Our credit card system is down. Since my credit card company gives double points per dollar I lost out pretty good on a $60 tab. A little annoying since I don't like to carry cash on hand.
We were never asked if our food was good or needed anything else. Poor customer service.
Your not going to get repeat business with that kind of service.
author: Alan L.

description:
Amazing Cuban food in the midst of the mission. I had the chicken and my friend had the pork, both were off the chain. Add in the Yuca fries on the side and it was a delight. Very reasonably priced as well. 

Additionally the staff was wonderful. Very helpful in their suggestions and very polite. To boot, I left my bag there and we were the last people before closing. They were kind enough to carefully set it aside keep it safe. 

We'll definitely be coming back soon.
author: eric k.

description:
I"ll keep this short and honest:  The food was okay... the service? It was terrible.  

I waited too long to order and then waited even longer for the food to arrive even though it wasn't super busy. 

Once my plate arrived I had to wait for another long while because there were no utensils, even though I told the waitress politely that I needed a fork... it took a long while for one to even arrive - I even saw her serving other people while I waited patiently for her to bring me something I could eat my food with.

Also...  they forgot my drink - never brought it to me. I reminded the waitress at the end of the meal to take the drink off the tab since I never go it. She did take the drink off but when I checked... there was a surcharge of a $1.00 for using a credit card... even though the bill was paid with cash. wtf?

At this point I just walked out the door, didn't care any more, but I still left a tip... plus the credit card surcharge... for paying in cash : /

This place can be a lot better if the service was at least descent, but it was just one bad thing after another.  I can't recommend.
author: Christiani C.

description:
This is a great spot in the Mission with authentic Puerto Rican and Cuban food.

To start we ordered the Picadillo, Chicken, and Veggie Empanadas. All of them were good! Loved the Chicken especially!

We ordered Pasteles which my Husband loved. For our main dishes we had the Pollo Española which had great flavors. It was similar to the Chicken in the empanada. Completely different than anything I have had but totally yummy! 

We had the Lechón, and shared a side of Habichuelas. The Lechón was very yummy. All of the plates were very generous and super tasty. We had delish leftovers for two additional meals.

I loved the ambiance and the music made us want to get up and dance salsa! Our server was very attentive and even brought out flan to celebrate a birthday in our party. For dessert I really enjoyed the Guava Turnover. It was fabulous, save room or take one to go!
author: Caro S.

description: I REALLY like his space. There was a family party type event going on with tons of music and singing. Since the place is really small customers were sat right in the midst of their celebration. It was great. Food was really good. I'll go again.
author: Rodney W.

description: The food was really good. I enjoyed the ropa vieja, the meat was tender and just right. For appetizer I got the yucca Frita ( It was my first time trying it and it was definitely interesting taste. Kind of taste like fries but it wasn't.) Lastly, I had the Alcapurrias and I would recommend people to try that one also.
author: Faith W.

description: Nice little place for very good food and service.  Watched a TV review of this place.  The review was on point!!! Will come back for more! If you're in SF, it's a must do on your checklist!
author: Em J.

description: Great service! Good sangria, and delicious tostones and yucca! Stopping here was on a whim and completly loved it!
author: Lauren A.

description: Delicious food, friendly staff. Everything I had tasted great!! Will be going back. The plantains were sweet and a desert all in itself. Get the Puerto Rican rice!
author: Christine E.

description:
Puerto Rican and Cuban food isn't as common in San Francisco as on the East Coast - this spot has a little slice of it. The tostones are prepared well and they even have Malta - one of my favorite drinks from Puerto Rico.

Props to them for also having a Cuban Sandwich - tampa staple and tradition - we do host the annual National Cuban Sandwich Fest after all.
author: Carlos H.

description: Sangria sangria, we tried the white sangria and it was really good. You always have to try the sangria in a latin/Hispanic/cubano culture lol, it helps to judge the rest of the night. On a date we ordered the empanadas, which came out hot and tasty, yummy; It was two so it's basically an appetizer. Then we ordered the Mofongo which was fulfilling and cooked with love. Then we had the Ropa Vieja! We shared all three plates so it was the right amount, obviously you can order just one plate for yourself and still have a great meal. I would definitely recommend those 3 to try out, however I have to go back and give the Yuka a try again. Wasn't impressed considering in Mother land Nicaragua they are cooked a certain way. The vibe was welcoming and homey so I'll give it another shot. Recommend for something low key and good vibes
author: Santiago E.

description: This place is truly a gem. Having been to Cuba and Puerto Rico, it was an amazing treat to relive those cultures here. We ordered the mofongo with shrimp and the spinach empanadas. Everything was amazing, but those empanadas were BOMB! The service was also excellent, and the waitress was very helpful with choice selection. There is also music, which creates a nice vibe. I'll definitely be back!!!
author: Tish H.

description: The food was exceptionally flavorful.  Simply delicious. There were four of us and we ordered Mofongo, ceviche, yuka fries, the flank steak dish and the shrimp dish. We all shared.   I can't wait to go back to have the Mofongo all to myself. Yummmmmmmm!!!!!
author: Alicia S.

description: An authentic taste of Puerto Rico in the mission. The food is amazing. The prices are more then reasonable dare I say cheap for SF given the generous portions. It's a small cozy welcoming place. Chill vibe with music and a very friendly staff. Despite my dislike of a sunglass wearing bleached blond food network star loving this place, the food speaks for itself. Got the vaca frita, a crispy shredded beef dish with onions wth the Puerto Rican rice. The beef was crispy and flavorful and the rice was the perfect balance to the meat. For appetizers got the yucca frites, tostones con mojo, and alcapurras. All were solid and good. The food here is great and authentic and you can't  beat the price and portions. One of my favorite places in all of San Francisco.
author: Peter P.

description:
I remember first trying El Nuevo Frutilandia when they were at the San Francisco Street Food Festival a few years back.  I had their Lechon and it blew my mind (bit.ly/1kKi5zG).  The pork was so tender and flavorful!  So after totally enjoying that sampling,  I was really looking forward to visiting their restaurant.  Well it took a while, but I finally made it over with a few friends.

Even though I was completely set on ordering their Lechon, there were a lot of things on the menu that sounded tempting like their Cubano Sandwich, their Tostones Con Mojo, their Garlic Shrimp (Limon Ajo Camarones), and Chile Relleno.  I still stuck with the plan and ordered the Lechon Horneado, and then decided on splitting their specialty Veggie Mofongo with my friends.  We also ordered a pitcher of their Guava Sangria.

Guava Sangria -- http://bit.ly/29VYBpT
White wine, guava
Very refreshing!  And it paired well with everything we ordered.  If you're going with a small group of people, definitely order the pitcher!!

Veggie Mofongo -- http://bit.ly/2a49ngu
Hand mashed garlic plantains topped with a tomato sofrito
This was really good!  The plantain mash was moist and had some good flavor together with the tomato sofrito  I was really surprised with the portion size because it was huge!  If you're dining here solo, unless you have a huge appetite, I wouldn't order this if you plan to order an entree after it.  This really could be a meal in itself.  Especially if you get one of the mofongos stuffed with meat.  I was definitely glad I was splitting this with my friends.

Lechon Horneado -- http://bit.ly/29IaNI4
Slow roasted pork marinated in garlic, pineapple, caribbean spices.  Ordered with Arroz Con Grandules which is Puerto Rican style rice with pigeon peas, smoked ham and bacon
Finally!!  And the first bite I had of the pork took me back to when I enjoyed it at the SF Street Food Fest.  Just like I described earlier, the Lechon is so tender and the flavor just explodes in your mouth!  They have it down to a science!  The Arroz Con Grandules is a must order with the Lechon.  It's almost like a ham and bacon paella and just completes the whole pork trinity.  And I must mention the portion size, it's a lot of food!!  Because I had the mofongo earlier, I was only able to finish half of my dish.

Overall, I say El Nuevo Frutilandia is must try in the Mission!  It's a really good spot when you're in the mood for some Cuban comfort food.  The food is delicious, huge portions, and the prices are easy on your wallet.  I definitely plan on returning again to try their Cubano Sandwich, and also all their other entrees since the whole menu sounds amazing.  It will be extremely hard to resist ordering another Lechon Horneado though.  It's so good!!!
author: Rodney H.

description:
Two locals introduced me to this awesome Cuban joint and I am glad they did! The food here is outstanding. We started with the white sangria which I highly recommend! Soo good! We also ordered the mofongo to start with and split it 3 ways. This is a very filling dish so you do not need a lot of it.

I ordered the chile rellenos as my main course. It was also great! I liked all the fresh veggies and the kick from the peppers. You can order any dish with plain rice or have it with meat and beans added in (Spanish style) which is what I did and was very good.

Our waitress was very friendly and made sure everything turned out how we wanted it. The restaurant itself is not large but I was there on a Thursday for dinner and it was mostly empty surprisingly! I highly recommend checking this place out when in the area or if you are searching for some great Cuban food!
author: Jennifer H.

description: El Nuevo Fruitlandia was fantastic. I could go on and on, but I won't   Great food, well priced with fantastic service. If we lived in SF we be there weekly, it was that good. Don't miss this gem.
author: lee g.

description: The food was great but a little pricey, trying to find parking was horrible had to park 3 blocks away a bigger downfall was the first time we went there they were closed due to a private party so the owner gave us a business card signed by him and his wife with a 30% discount but when we presented the card to our waitress she went to the back and came back out and told us that another owner said they could only give us 10%, I don't know how many owners there are but the need all to be on the same sheet of music!!!
author: Angel S.

description: My mom's Cuban and my dad's Puerto Rican and I actually grew up in Puerto Rico and I can honestly say this place is the bomb. Super authentic and delicious in every way. I went last night in need of some home cooking in the wake of Hurricane Maria and this spot delivered. I had some of the alcapurrias (fritters) stuffed with picadillo (ground beef) and they were bomb. Then I had the vaca frita (shredded flank steak) with rice and black beans and it was amazing. This is my favorite dish my mom makes, and this was up there with hers (actually even a more flavorful). I also had the passion fruit mango juice and it was super tasty. In short, I can't recommend this place enough!
author: Ana M.

description: Great people but not your traditional Cuban restaurant. The Mission location has limited parking and it's normal problems. The restaurant is clean and the staff is great. The place is a mix of cooking styles which for me is not great but it was still good food.
author: William F.

description:
A colleague turned me on to this place in the Mission.  It's a classic hole in the wall with little signage out front.  Apparently this Puerto Rican restaurant has been here for many years.

To be honest I know very little about Puerto Rican food as my only other dining experience was at SOL in San Rafael which I enjoyed.  However, El Nuevo Frutilanda was a much different, at least to my taste, cuisine.

And that's a good thing.

We began our evening dinner with the Ceviche a wonderful mix of shrimp and fish that was marinated with a unbelievable tasty pineapple salsa that was heaven to my taste buds.  Most of their dishes are served with Taro Chips which is a fried root vegetable sliced like a large flat potato chip and lightly salted. I think it was the first time that I've had one and I must say that it was delicious

Our entrees consisted of the Pollo A La Espenola which was nice cubes of chicken breast sautéed in onions and red bell peppers in a butternut carrot spiced sauce. The sauce was both sweet and tangy very delicious actually.  The entrée was topped off with a portion of rice. My partner ordered the Ropa Vieja which was marinated shredded beef in a tomato based sauce with rice and black beans. The sauce was very tasty and was totally different than the sauce that my dish had.  Like in all the great regional cuisines such as New Orleans it has been my experience that the sauces really make the dish and at El Nuevo Frutilandia it is all about the sauce.

Our dinner was topped off with a wonderful freshly baked plantain tart which melted in our mouths. 

San Francisco is a fabulous culinary destination full of multi ethnic cuisines  El Nuevo Frutilandia is a fine example of that - offering up great food, at reasonable prices in a neighborhood rich in fantastic dining alternatives.  We found it to be one of the City's best kept secrets.

We will be back.....
author: Nick C.

description: this place has been on my list to try for a while  ...I' just happen to b in the neighborhood  and decided to give it a try. and my taste buds were happy. It was a hard decision trying to figure out what to eat.. I cant want to come back good flavorful food good atmosphere ..the staff was so nice and helpful
author: Elisha S.

description: This place is delicious!! Customer service was great, and we tried a little bit of everything on the menu including the empanadas- everything was great!!
author: Mel N.

description:
tl;dr -- good food, WORST. SERVER. EXPERIENCE. EVER.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Showed up a little after 9 last night (Yelp says 10pm close). My GF had been interested in it for some time, so we decided to check it out. We waffled on sitting near the door (my GF gets cold) but a seat opened up near the bar and we took that.

We ordered, switched to another table by the wall when it opened up, and otherwise enjoyed the meal. The food was really good. I was looking forward to coming back again and trying the other dishes. The ambience was nice too, and, up to this point, the server was friendly (mostly) and accommodating. There was an odd tic from her when we asked about moving tables (makes sense now) but otherwise the service was fine.

The problems came as the meal was winding down. The 4-top had filled up, so there's a group of 5 there and the 2 of us. My GF is not a fast eater, so we she's hurriedly trying to finish her food. The server (woman in black pants and shirt, with dark hair) started being very pushy. She was grabbing plates with food on them, etc. I was scrambling to push the food onto plates we still had. It was weird -- she made it seem like they had a plate shortage in the kitchen. She was very impatient. Things escalated VERY QUICKLY.

* She asks for our carafe of sangria, saying we should pour it into our glasses.
* I said we'd do that in a moment (my glass was 1/2 full, the rest was for my GF but her glass was already full).
* She replied that she needed the carafe and was going to take it no matter what.
* Stunned by her answer, I said "no, you aren't, we aren't done with it"
* She said "Yes, I'm going to take that carafe"'

*insert awkward stand-off here*

Stunned, I pour the rest into my glass (leaving none for my GF). Carafe is taken. Waitress comes back with the check.

Meanwhile we're wondering WTF just happened. We had never been treated like that before. She wants a tip? I've never in my life left less than 15%, even for the worst service. I wrote as much in a note on the back of the receipt (with a frowny face) and left 10%. I felt shitty leaving that little. I know servers work hard, but this was unbelievable treatment. I didn't know what do.

I signed the receipt and put it in my pocket, planning to leave it (with the note) as we were leaving.

Waitress comes back and demands the signed receipt. I said I would leave it when we left the restaurant (I didn't want to get into with her if she read the note on the back before we were able to depart). Things escalate AGAIN:

* She said she needed the receipt
* I said I'd leave it as we left, and asked for a to-go box
* She said we couldn't have a box since I wouldn't give her the receipt
* I said if we couldn't have the left-over food then I needed to leave less money
* She then said she'd CALL THE POLICE since we weren't paying (she'd already run my card, btw...)
* I said of course we're paying, but I'd leave the receipt as we departed.
* She then said they DIDN'T HAVE ANY TO-GO BOXES (clearly lying)

This is just dumb. What if I just hadn't signed the receipt yet? In retrospect, I should've waited to do so. But I'd already signed it so she's standing there demanding I hand it to her.

* She stood there impatiently and awkwardly, then said "I'm going to have to ask you to leave"

Now I'm confused. Does she want me to pay or to leave?

At this point it's clear she's having some sort of power trip. The whole thing is freaking surreal. My GF got up and walked to the back by the bar and asked for a to-go box. She was given one. The server walked off as this was happening.

As we're hurriedly trying to collect the food, a 300 lb. morbidly obese fellow comes to the table and asks me to "step outside". Those were his *exact words*.

WTF? Are they really threatening to _ASSAULT_ me over her bitchy behavior? WTF is going on? Fed up and not wanting to aid in her completely unnecessary escalation, I left and waited outside for my GF to collect her things.

Honestly, we were nothing but polite the whole meal. We just wanted a to-go box and to finish the things we ordered without them being forcefully taken away from us. Either that, or be able to depart with them.

I don't know what her problem was. In retrospect, she seemed to have a chip on her shoulder the whole meal. Maybe it was late and she was in a hurry to leave, but the 4-top was still sitting there, unmolested, with a 1/3 carafe of sangria and half-empty plates.

We were excessively polite, even as I was being BOUNCED FROM A RESTAURANT and THREATENED WITH ASSAULT and a CALL TO THE POLICE for doing nothing more than wanting to-go boxes and holding on to the receipt until I left because she was so completely rude and unprofessional.

People like that should not be servers. Are you kidding me? How can you treat customers like that?

I'm now unhappy that I gave her an $8 tip. I want that back.

She was awful - ruined an otherwise good meal.

Avoid!
author: Iago D.

description: Love this place. A small, pretty and colorful restaurant in the middle of Mission District stolen from Puerto Rico. It made me miss my time in San Juan!
author: Ugur O.

description: My husband and I were staying in a near by Airbnb and it just so happened that the owner of El Nuevo Frutilandia was our host and mentioned stopping by during our stay. I am SOOO happy we did! I had never had never had Cuban food prior to this experience, and all I can say is it was an amazing experience! Delicious food/sangria, affordable, and friendly. I ordered the Picadillo a La Havana and my husband got the Cuban sandwich and we shared a craft of sangria with some empanadas (chicken ones were the best). HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!
author: Brittany M.

description: My family & I went to Frutilandia today, I was our first time going here & out experience was amazing! We got there right before they closed but they still welcomed us in and served us food. The hosts Jennifer was so kind & patient with us, she made our experience unforgettable. She also gave us some free desert. The food tasted amazing I had the empanadas! I definitely recommend this place !!!
author: Lorena P.

description: Don't go there exactly when it opens because sometimes they maybe late. The show was on diners, drivins and dives so it has some good food. We weren't impressed with the Cuban sandwich maybe it's the sandwich, just ham, shredded pork and cheese it's a dry sandwich, but the mofongo on the other hands was great. Nice staff and 20%tip is on ticket for parties of 6. Definitely a pricey joint about $$$ or $$$$ for cost. But try other plates you may enjoy.
author: Mace S.

description: This place is amazing.  I went here for the first time back in 2008 and food was not all that great.  Kind of dry, the alcapurrias were oily and it didn't really appeal to my palate.  Fast forward 9 years later, and under new ownership, the place is awesome.  Food is fresh and cooked made to order, the setting is cute and quaint and displays the flags of Cuba and Puerto Rico adjacent to each other.  We ordered the plantains, pollo a la española, pasteles, yucca frita, and they gave us tostones on the house! The service is soooooo warm and inviting.  Food is great! Can't wait to come back to this beautiful gem on 24th street...
author: Jill P.

description: I randomly walked into this place by chance and it was such a good choice. I ordered the garlic shrimp with rice dish and empanadas to start. As soon as we tried the empanadas we ordered another round they were so amazing. At the end of our meal we ordered a sweet empanada as dessert which was covered in condensed milk. This place is amazing and I will definitely make the trip to eat here again!
author: Renee R.

description: They didn't have bread at noon for lunch. Counters were dirty. Place was completely empty despite being on DDD. Looks like the locals know there's a problem.
author: John S.

description: Absolutely terrible. Let me preface this by saying I have never given a 1 star review before but the service and food I received here yesterday warrants this. They had one server for the whole place. I ordered a glass of wine, waited about 30 minutes and never got it. Then I see her giving other people drinks who got there after me so we flag her down and I order two at once, knowing I will probably never see her again. Then I proceed to order my dinner and guess what? She also forgets to put that in! So after I waited about an hour and a half for dinner and I never even ended up getting it! I did get the empanada appetizer at the beginning which was mediocre at best--honestly more fried dough than any filling. I tried some of my friend's dinner (since I never got mine) and it was so bad that I was actually relieved I didn't get mine. I think this place takes the cake for my absolute worst dining experience, ever.
author: Catalina M.

description:
A while back I spent three months in Miami and got to really appreciate the local cuisine, especially the Cuban restaurants.
Back home in SF I had not been able to have the same experience until I found this place.
The Vaca Frita was as good as anything I had eaten in Miami, and they even offered Mamey milk shake!
The restaurant is jointly Cuban and Puerto Rican, so some dishes are a happy mix of both, Puerto Rican rice with Cuban beef, etc.
I did not try the Mofongo (next time), but the Tres Leches cake was easily among the best I have had anywhere.
Compared to the Cuban corner places in Miami, the food here is a little more - for lack of better words - cleaned up, lighter, and the portions are more "reasonable".
Staff is very friendly and helpful, restaurant is comfortable, small enough to be cozy, just a little prone to noise maybe.
author: Lars A.

description:
Our family has always been looking for a restaurant to feed our culture and tonight we found it. I hugely impressed by the owners and how they paid attention to their patrons. The food was magnificent took me back to Puerto Rico. I will definately go again. 
Thank you so much from the party if 11.
author: Charon P.

description: This is the best food ever!!! A lil pricy but totally worth it. I got the vaca frita as recommended by the waitress and I loved it. The taro chips are super tasty. Wish I had bought a side of them.
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Really love this place   You can't go wrong with the yucca frita and lechón asado. Leave room for dessert and have the pastelito de guava   It comes with a passion fruit sorbet. YUM
I also love the service.  No pretensions and great refills when you need it
author: elizabeth t.

description:
Best Cuban in San Francisco. Owner is VERY cool and friendly- always smiling and in the restaurant. The restaurant was featured on Diners, Drive-In, and Dives with Guy Fieri. Food came out shocking quick and was VERY GOOD. This may the only good Cuban place in the Bay- trust me, we looked around. Highly recommend!!

Edit: THE TRES LECHE CAKE IS SOOOOOOOOOO GOOD-- MUST TRY!!
author: Theo K.

description: My mouth is watering thinking about Frutilandia! I've never really tried Cuban/Puerto Rican food, but I cleared my plate. The place is small and cozy. Service is awesome. Highly recommend if you're in the Mission District.
author: Cynthia T.

description:
We heard El Nuevo Fruitlandia had good sangrias so we had to check it out.  My husband had the red sangria and I had the white sangria and they were both excellent.  We use to go to Cha Cha Cha for sangria, not any more. El Nuevo Fruitlandia's sangrias were not only excellent, the atmosphere was quaint and had a comfortable vibe.  The ceviche was also very good, it was fresh and savory and sweet with chunks of mangos and fresh fish. 

The prices were reasonable and the service was good and friendly .  We are definitely coming back with friends and family.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Bruh the food so it don't make no damn sense. That Vaca frita tho . Be on point ever time. My lady loves the ropa vaja or whatever. We even ordered a catering sizes once to bring to a party. Great date place and great with a small group. And them appetizers won't let you down so eat the hell up.
author: Alterrique I.

description: I was disappointed with this place. I was so excited when I got my food that looked good. I had order shrimp also served with rice. My dish was so salty and the rice was a half cook.
author: Pinarat S.

description: I came here because I had a craving for fried plaintains, and they did not disappoint. I ordered both the side dish version AND the dessert plaintains. Both were delicious. With a side of sour creme and a splash of Tabasco, the plantanos maduros were a sweet, sour, and spicy delight to my tastbuds. The empanadas de plántano were flaky and paired perfectly w my café cubano. Mmm. Mmm. Mmm
author: Jocelyn A.

description:
I have been coming to this restaurant since I was a young girl it has been in my neighborhood for many years. It had been many years since I had returned. 
I came in today and I was pleasantly surprised to find out that the food is still outstanding. The remodel also was very cool. We enjoyed the service Nick provided, he was very pleasant, knowledgeable and had a charismatic way about him. 
We had the Cuban sandwich, tasty, but it needed to be pressed more. We also had both of the shrimp dishes offered, both were very good. I had the ropa vieja with arroz con gandules, the beef was on point, however the rice lacked the sofrito taste and salty pork flavor I am accustomed to. We also had the yuca appetizer, which was bland and needed salt. We were pleasantly surprised by the fried plantains, sweet and nicely cooked. 
All in all I would recommend it and will return to taste the other dishes on the menu.
author: IRMA C.

description:
I have to admit, I came here because this restaurant was featured on the Food Network. I have to admit another thing... I had barely eaten all day because of how excited I was to try this place out - and I wanted to leave enough room in my tummy. I left the place happily stuffed!

Was it as good as I hyped it up to be to my boyfriend (based on the show it as featured in)? Yes... and no. Yes, the shrimp dish that I had (the spicy one) was amazing and you must get their Cuban beans. Yes, the yucca fries were a deliciously fried and the pickled cabbage was so good (I asked for extra). No, the plantain empanada's that I was super excited, weren't all that great. Yes, the service was awesome (thank you Raven - hope you got your lashes done by my girl)! 

Tip: Ask for their spicy aioli - so good! 

Will I be back? YES! And I'll have to get a different dessert so that I can update my review to 5 stars. 

Side note - I am dying to go to Cuba and the decor and ambiance of this restaurant made me feel like I was in Cuba for the hour that I dined here.
author: Anastasia N.

description:
What happened?

( have eaten here at least once a year for the past 8 years )

Meh.

Had the beef with red chile sauce and the pork sauteed dish; both in a similar red sauce. How strange! Each dish comes with a pinch of pickled onions and a large scoop of ok tasting rice. $15.95 and $14.95 respectively. Kinda spendy for what you get.

Had to ask for my water to be refilled. Twice in 30 minutes. There were a total of 9 people in the restaurant.

C'mon E N F ! get your game back up!

FYI,  the Cubano sandwich is now $18.00.
author: Bert K.

description:
This place was cute. The ceviche mixto was pretty delicious. Came here with a groupon. The one waitress was very nice, welcoming, but seemed kind of flustered. The food was Okay to good. I wouldn't rave about it, but I wouldn't mind coming back here again. Food seemed fresh.

I got the shrimp with Creole camarones (Shrimp with the creole Caribbean sauce). It was good, but kind of salty. My brother got the Wednesday special Pork chop with mango sauce. The pork itself was not bad, but the sauce was AMAZING to me! My brother thought it was okay, so we switched plates :D

Beans were good. Rice was good. Place seemed authentic and quaint.

-1 star for the wait time. Our ceviche came out right away (within 5-10 minutes), but we waited ~45 minutes for our food to come out, which is a little ridiculous considering we were the second table to be seated right as they opened. We also came on a Tuesday once, and they weren't open. We waited 10 minutes past 6PM and I didn't see anyone, no signs, nothing.

-0.5 stars for it being above average food, but not the best I've ever had. 3.5 stars but will round to 4 because this place is cute.
author: Josie W.

description:
Found this place on Yelp purely by chance and decided to come because it was open and we wanted somewhere in the Mission that wasn't crowded and serving Mexican food.

If Wendy is looking after you tonight, you're gonna have a good time. She's friendly, funny, and attentive, a winning combination in a waitress! Skills possibly honed through her past gig as a bartender. ;) Anyways, if you're having trouble deciding, you should trust her judgment. Vaca Frita vs. Ropa Vieja? Hands down, Vaca Frita, said she. And we couldn't get enough of the crispy, citrusy pieces of steak or savory taro root chips. 

Wendy's recommendations turned out to be more winning than my fellow Yelpers. I got the much touted Mofongo (with pork) out of curiosity, and while it was interesting, I wouldn't order it again. It was a mush of plantains and pork in garlicky sauce that wasn't evenly seasoned. A dish that struggled for direction and just sort of collapsed into a heap. 

The portions here are pretty small for what you pay, but there are few places to get a clean but authentic Puerto Rican experience such as the one at Frutilandia. The bright interior is sparingly but charmingly decorated in bright colors and a TV plays soundless channels. Somehow, everything just belongs together, like the coffee can turned silverware container on each table. It's a wonderful place for a peaceful meal before a busy night in the Mission!
author: Helen S.

description:
Well, this would be the first 5 that I've given out.  Heard about the place so of course I had to try it.  

Beef Empanadas-very tasty and cooked perfect. The dough was nice light brown color and flaky. Only wish more came with the order. 

Vaca frita-was tender and delicious. Cooked perfect as well. 

Lechon-so tender, flavor was awesome

Beans two different ones, both very good. Yummy. 

Mofungo-good flavor, very good. 

Tres leche-to die for. Wth. Have to try it. 

Okay enough about the food, the waitress was great with great service.
author: Will E.

description: The only reason I came here is because I saw it on tv. There were only 4 people eating here, including my group. Even like this I waited 40 minutes for my food to come out. The table behind me complained about their 2 Cuban sandwiches taking so long. Not only the food is slow, but the servers are also slow and lost. I waited about 8 minutes for someone to bring me a menu, I finally had to go ask for one and the same problem to order the food. My food was too salty and dried. At the end, they expect a minimum of 18% tip. That guy from the tv show bs me. Will never go back
author: Jonh S.

description:
Service was awesome, make sure to get the carafe of red sangria, ropa vieja and ceviche. NEW fave place in the mission. 

Update: another 5 stars!
author: Rob A.

description: Ya know there aren't many Puerto Rican's in California compared to New York or Florida. That being said it's even harder to find outstanding Puerto Rican/Cuban cuisine. Well look no further! You'd swear your beloved  Abuela was cooking in the kitchen when you smell and taste the food here. Outstanding food and service. This is my favorite Puerto Rican/Cuban restaurant in the Bay Area. There are others but none has the feeling of home and family quite like this little gem. Outstanding restaurant!
author: Victor G.

description:
What a great neighborhood find!  After seeing a movie that served Cuban food we found this cool spot.  Great inside space, looks like it could be in Little Havana in Cuba. Ropa Vieja, was spiced just right and even has a small but nice wine list.  

A gem...
author: George H.

description: Good service & food was great. My friend recommended me to come here. They're prices are affordable.
author: Christina V.

description: shirmp mofongo twas alright you get 2 pieces of shrimp thats it... parada 22 is way better
author: Edwin I.

description: My first time ever arriving to the restaurant, they were turning away customers 2 hours early before closing on a Friday night because they ran out of food. Never heard a restaurant having to close early because they ran out... disappointing and unprofessional.
author: Kathleen M.

description: I'm not super familiar with Puerto Rican/Cuban food... however the food was impeccable. A perfect hole in the wall, the atmosphere was lovely. It felt like a delicious home cooked meal.
author: Ethan A.

description: Being 100 percent Puerto Rican and having been to my share of Cuban/PR food restaurants I have to this say this place just didn't do it for us. My whole family was here, visiting from the East Coast and it left us all disappointed. All food was missing the typical sabor you taste while eating our foods. One could argue that this place is meant to be more fusion and not authentic then I argue, at least cook your rice correctly because the texture was not just different but "off." I could go on and on. Service was meh. Parking was hard to find. We won't be back.
author: Melisa K.

description:
Fantastic.

Been here twice now and I know I'll be having cravings.

What go get:
Pork mofongo 
Any of the entrees although I'm partial to the spicy Camarrones creole
Flan!!! Done so right 

You can get Spanish style rice for extra. 

If you're looking for authentic Cuban/Puerto Rican food, this is it. Definitely bringing friends here in the future.
author: Alice H.

description:
I'm a daughter of Cuban refugees who grew up in Miami and now lives in San Francisco. I wish someone had prepared me for the fact that great Cuban food would be ridiculously hard to come by in this otherwise incredibly international city. I'm talking real, solid Cuban food that tastes just like the stuff I grew up with and not a weird fusion.

And that's exactly why El Nuevo Frutilanda is such a treasure. It is one of the *very few* places in San Francisco where I can get my all-time favorite Cuban dish, vaca frita (literally "fried cow"), and it's absolutely outstanding here! 

If you've never tasted vaca frita, you're missing out. Shredded, tender garlicy-lime-marinated skirt steak that's been fried until crispy like bacon (mmmm!), served with carmelized onions, rice, and perfectly seasoned black beans. ¡Riquissimo! as my mom would say. One bite and you'll want to start a revolution. ;-)

Not only that, but Frutilandia serves something from my childhood that's even rarer -- mamey smoothies. Not familiar with mamey? Wondering what it tastes like? There's no way I could compare to anything because it's probably a flavor unlike any you've ever had. Just order it, live a little. It is one of the most delectable fruit flavors out there. Frutilandia's version of it is slightly watered down compared to the way my mom made it, but it is so refreshing on a warm day anyway. You won't find this kind of smoothie at any project juice or any Mexican restaurant. In fact, this might be the only place in town that serves them.

I realize that going on and on about foods from my childhood might not necessarily appeal to most Yelpers out there who didn't grow up Cuban, but I really don't think it's just the nostalgia talking. Cuban food is practically designed to comfort and nourish you. El Nuevo Frutilandia captures this so well, I hope they stay in business through the ages. And if the owners are reading, I recommend that you guys market/advertise your Cuban offerings much more openly, especially now that U.S. trips to Cuba are opening up!
author: Christina M.

description:
Amazing food; perfectly seasoned entrees,  just like on the island, drink was perfect and dessert was delightful. 
Awesome service; our waiter was polite,  knowledgeable and quick. 
Great music; classic salsa, bugaloo, bomba, and plena.  

Was extremely satisfied.
author: Damian R.

description: We stopped here before attending a reggaeton concert at Roccapulco and had a really nice time! The ceviche was very tender and tasty, and the fried yucca was a new discovery that we enjoyed. I also really liked the sangria. The best part of the visit was talking with the owners, who are wonderfully friendly and entertaining. We had traveled to Cuba a month before going to Fruitilandia, and had a great time talking to them about Cuba and the Caribbean. I'd go here again and would recommend Fruitilandia to others!
author: Jeff S.

description: I've never eaten like that different taste of food. It's extremely good. I'm waiting to go again.
author: Ayca Y.

description: I had the chicken dish which was not great: the chicken was dry and the sauce was basic. It cost 15$ at lunch and the portion was quite small. The decor of this place is super nice and the service was good. However, I would not eat here again
author: Adar G.

description:
Service was good and so was the food.  Nothing crazy good that I would cross the Bay Bridge for.

Had the veggie mofongo which was tasty and the lemon garlic shrimp.  The shrimp was good and cooked well, but it tasted more like Italian fare than Puerto Rican/Cuban.  Portion was small.  Had the platanos maduros which were great, but $6.50 for 6 pieces was a bit much to charge for such a small side.
author: Caroline K.

description: Great Cuban food and great service with nice ambiance. Really glad I tried this and I would recommend the vaca fritta but missing a star because I think this dish is missing a sauce that would make it unbelievable. Shrimp and apps were great but the remoulade sauce was uninspired. I'll be back for sure as overall it was great!
author: Shariq H.

description:
Awesome food and fabulous service! Great ambiance!

Will certainly dine here again.!!
author: Jay J.

description: Friendly employees who make you feel so well take care of! Try the empanadas- they're so delicious I would order like 3 plates of them to make one giant meal!
author: Kara D.

description: Traditional Cuban and Puerto Rican food with fast service. Friendly staff is welcoming. We loved the chicken empanadas, the beef are great too. Owner sat and chatted with us after our meal, and made us feel very welcome.  We are never disappointed with the amazing food, sangria, dessert and, especially, the service.
author: Margaret P.

description: The first time we came here we really enjoyed the food.  The staff was very nice and attentive.  The 2nd time we came here the food was excellent again.  Every dish we had was really good and the Tres Leche is so yummy.  We ordered both types of Sangria ( Guava/white wine) & ( Mango/red wine).  We will definitely be back.
author: Alett B.

description: Loved this place!  We have walked past this little gem in the mission, many many times and finally went in after all the good reviews from Yelp!  Well! we should have gone in long ago, because it was a FANTASTIC FIND!  Its a small, homey, space that is very inviting and the staff is very friendly!  We went with our two little children, and all of the Empanadas (chicken, Beef, and the desert Plantain one) were very good.  The black beans and rice are flavored to perfection and if I closed my eyes, I felt like was back in Miami with my family!  We will be back, to try the Ropa Viella and the Cuban Sandwich (which we called Media Noche' in Miami) .  Fantastic place, perfect location, great food and friendly staff.....what else can you ask for?
author: M. R.

description:
I'm giving this 5 stars because of flavor.

This is the best PR/Cuban food (Cuba Rican) food I've had away from Miami.

In NY I found PR food but no real Cuban food, so finding this in SF felt like pure luck.

The mofongo and pork were moist and flavorful.

The yucca was good (not dry, not dripping in oil), and the garlic sauce was almost looe my grandma makes it!

Want to try more, but I imagine the sofrito and ropa vieja will be beautiful since the mofongo has a little sofrito on top (sin carne).

Definitely go here!
Only down side: average portions (not large, not tiny) and on the low end of pricey (I usually go to places where main dishes are $8-15 rather than $14-19.
author: Ellie M.

description:
Sometimes I like to keep my favorite places a secret in hopes that I can get a table without waiting in line (sneaky, I know). I went in a couple nights ago and lo and behold I found out the secret is about to be OUTED on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives! 

Things are about to get crazy--I'm going to have to eat here every week for the next month just to prepare myself for the hoards of people that will be lining up. 

The food is off the hook and there's no other place like it. Take Cuban deliciousness and mix it with lick-your-chops Puerto Rican dishes and you have something really special. I'm so happy for everyone there and I hope you read this and love me enough to sneak me in the back door for a table every once in a while : )

Congrats and well-deserved!
author: Shelley C.

description: The service was great, the server was very attentive. Food was ready in a flash. Only drawback was the pricing it felt a little pricey. If you check in for your first visit you get a 10% discount. A plus but most likely won't come back due to the price. My wife ordered a ceviche, she said it was good. I ordered the chile relleno, also good. The mofongo felt a little dry. Let's keep in mind, I'm not well versed with Caribbean food. So I dont think my opinion on the tastyness of the food is valid but, I did enjoy my meal.
author: Fredy V.

description: This place is soooo good and great service!!!! Clean and great place to eat. The guava sangria was pretty good! I had the picadillo and it was awesome. And did I say the service was amazing? They're super nice, love the waitresses.
author: Jamie B.

description: Wonderful place to eat authentic Puerto Rican food. The staff is friendly and totally love the salsa music in the background. Charming place that you all should definitely visit in the mission. You must try the vaca frita, alcapurria's, empanadas de platano maduro. Happy eating.
author: Maria C.

description: This is probably my favorite place so far that offers amazing yucca frita and sweet plantains. Also their sangria is really good.
author: Celeste D.

description:
So we'd come back since 2012, and things had taken a turn for the better. But revisiting tonight showed that once again, things are worse - and worse than ever, sadly. We noticed that the menus have changed - there's no more soup, unfortunately. The alcapurrias were a disturbing orange color (more than just too much annatto) and frankly weren't worth eating. The ropa vieja flavor was heavily dominated by green peppers, was tough, and the sauce was too runny. The cuban sandwich was fine though!

Furthermore, the service was pretty paltry too. We were quizzed about if we were willing to pay the $1.25 for pink beans instead of black when we'd asked for the former (this at a restaurant where the alcalpurrias are now $9!), and when we confirmed we wanted the pink beans and were fine to pay for them, black beans were still brought to our table - and when the situation was remedied, the beans themselves tasted terribly burned! Our "appetizer" arrived by the time we had almost finished our entrees. We asked if the platanos could be cooked without the butter, and were told this was impossible - too bad, since they have accommodated that request before. We were pretty sad to see what's going on here.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Great spot! 
So they have great happy hour deals on tapas and drinks (Wed thru Fri 5pm-7pm & sun 4pm-7pm) and THE BEST SANGRIA. I don't even like white wine and they make a guava white wine sangria and a mango red wine one, which are both to die for. 

As for food, it's a fusion of Cuban and Puerto Rican food. Very good empanadas, ceviche, shrimp dishes with different marinades of rice (as well as chicken, steaks, and pork in same manner), lots of bean sides, and yucca and plantains galore! The empanadas come with a great sauce!! Good portion sizes too and fun, local vibe. My friend spoke highly of the Cubano Sandwich. 

Guy Fieri filmed here for Food Network and they are super modest about it, which is cool because I'd brag about my restaurant being on TV. 

Total great date/group place and be ready to share because food envy gets real here.
author: Emily R.

description: Tried this restaurant for the first time tonight and really enjoyed our dinner.  I ordred the Chile Relleno and my brother had the Cuban sandwich. My Chile Relleno was made with a big fresh pepper, filled with cheese and accompanied with a flavorful sauce and rice.  My brother said his sandwich was also very good....  Definitely will be back, but will be torn between getting the Relleno again, or trying something different!
author: Frances B.

description: We had the best service! Miguel was delightful, speedy, efficient and knows his stuff as he helped us with what was best on the menu. We ordered Lechon (which was great) nice and flavorful, and shrimp mofongo which was not a disappointment! We left full and satisfied, absolutely coming back!
author: Angelica V.

description: Amazing food! Service was great and personable. Food tasted delicious. Very intimate place. Love it
author: Lolo P.

description:
The food was pretty good. I've been craving mofongo, alcapurrias (although a bit overcooked and hard, they were still delicious), and a real deal Cuban Sandwich for quite some time now. I've had pretty bad luck with Cuban Sandwiches lately in the Bay Area. The last one had arugula and tomatoes and no Swiss. It was a hipster ABOMINATION. Cuban Sandwiches are absolute perfection and the ingredients should NEVER EVER be altered. The only thing that should vary is the amount of love one puts in em. And not the amount of arugula like Habanas in Alameda. Yuck!
We did have to wait 10 minutes to be seen when we sat down. The young waitress, seemed to be a bit distracted by some young bucks sitting at the bar. She did, however help us a lot after our 10 min wait. The co-owner was super helpful and nice as well. 
We're from the East Coast and my wife is Boricua, so we know what to look for.

The mofongo was delicious, but they brought us 3 very, very little shrimp with garlic sauce to add. The cuban sandwich was good, but a bit salty.

Had to drop my review by 2 stars because the restaurant was closed when we showed up at 6 pm on a Wednesday for dinner. Drove all the way from Oakland took 30 mins to find parking and BAM CLOSED for no apparent reason. Sign on the door stated "Open."

Stay thirsty my friends
author: Themane D.

description:
This is a cute hole-in-the-wall spot for some Cuban fare. I enjoyed my food but didn't love it; then again, I don't think I generally love Cuban food. Our server wasn't completely reliable for a casual meal it's not a huge deal. 

THE WAIT: None on a Thursday night at about 7:30pm.

THE SERVICE: Not amazing. When our server first came around, she asked me three times in one conversation if I wanted a drink. Either she really wanted me to order a drink, or she legitimately forgot. She would forget little things--for example, she brought our Mofongo out and said she'd bring share plates but never did. 

COST: $68 total for 2 drinks, 1 app, 2 entrees, 1 dessert. A little pricey for the quality. Our dinner receipt: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#jsa9v2WGbdsloXiu0HJg_Q

MUST-HAVES: Tres Leches! The Mofongo was pretty good too.

Out of Ceviche Mixto.

TAPAS, SANDWICHES, DAILY SPECIALS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#AmMGmTKSA9KMKYDcDCLp5A
* Mofongo (garlic mashed plantains filled w/ our "Signature" roasted pork, topped w/ a tomato sofrito $10) - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#dSuEbtPP887h3bE4-_RRiQ
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#jf6UgPeC9TJKuiTVsW2DLg
pork filling: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#qqrslAHkj0NxfUjCvLcrXQ
Normally I'm not overly impressed with mashed plantains, but the fact that this was filled with this tasty roasted pork, the plantains had soaked up the meaty flavor, and the pork had soaked up all these great flavors, made this really unique and tasty!


SALADS, ENTREES (pt. 1): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w
* Lechon Horneado (succulent slow roast pork marinated in garlic, pineapple, Caribbean spices $14) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#-jA4oaVrkuxWf5FcYfflsA
Very juicy, tender pork. For this cut of meat, it's still a little on the dry side. Compared to my pork chops, this was much more moist. It's drenched in sauce, but biting through a thick chunk of meat, you do get to the dryer (though still soft) meat in the middle. Just me being picky. Rice & black beans were good.


ENTREES (pt. 2), SANGRIA: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#N3MQSz_pOTi4bB1_t4mniQ
* Chuletas de Cerdo Fritas (pork chops spiced w/ garlic & mango sauce, topped w/ sauteed onions $14) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#6hlk7Zo3gw5cQfxC1n3ibg
I was intrigued by the mango sauce, but couldn't taste this at all in the end. This ended up being a very basic pork chop dish, nothing too special. Came with rice & black beans.

* Guava Sangria (white wine, guava $6.50) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#hBXdP8R1BC4DPL6I4LnHjA
Light flavor-wise, like a tropical sangria. My boyfriend got a glass of this and moved to the Mango Sangria, which basically tasted like a red sangria.

Mango Sangria

SWEET TREATS: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#nY5oZV87SJF1MUdHPKlSog
* Tres Leches Cake (sponge cake soaked in evaporated milk, condensed milk & heavy cream, topped w/ cream cheese frosting $7) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/el-nuevo-frutilandia-san-francisco?select=7z7dSx5OhmVq7libj_0C_w#bpTQFcVHPgRVu6w1u1pOsQ
Wow, that was a *thick* layer of cream cheese frosting on top! I love my sweets but that was a little too intense. However, on the cake--I've been on the hunt for an amazing tres leches in SF and I think I've found my holy grail. This was intensely soft, moist, and heaven in our mouths.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
My  experience at Frutilandia, was a bit of a disappointment. Being myself from Cuba, I expected the food to be as good as I have had in restaurants in Miami . We had for appetizers tostones they where typical, the fried yucca; fried as if you where eating french fries with a mojo that was very bland. The mofongo was good for it being Puerto Rican. My Son had the vaca frita and that was delicious! The rest of us had the Cuban pork. It was tender but had no flavor of the common garlic/ cumin mojo as typically expected in chunks of pork at a Cuban restaurant. In fact it had the flavor of what you would expect carnitas to taste at a Mexican restaurant. We also ordered fried plantains on the side, unfortunately they where so chard/ black they where not edible. Unfortunately they made no attempt to rectify the situation, so I merely told our nice waitress not to charge us for that and they didn't. It does make me sad for me to say I will not eat here again.
Good luck, hope this helps?
author: D F.

description: The food was actually pretty good, at least the lemon garlic shrimp was.  The portion was small, the price was fairly large and they charged an extra $2 for a crushed piece  of bread.  But the main thing was that the place was so extremely loud that we ate a main course and got out of there for the sake of our ears. Service was iffy.  All in all, too bad, I wanted to have a pleasant meal.  It wasn't.
author: B W.

description: Hands down, one of the best PRican/Cuban restaurants in SF! Better than Sol and Havana Cuba.  The food was delicious and bursting with flavor! We ordered a little bit of everything. The pork mofongo was to die for.  Soooo much flavor! The chicken empanadas.  Wow.  The ceviche? Yum! We ordered lechon (so tender and loaded with flavor), ropa vieja (the sauce tasty) and shrimp platter, which came with arroz con gandules and habichuelas.  Soooo delicious.  I just can't say enough about this place.  It's a little hole in the wall on the Mission, with beautiful decor of PR and my favorite salsa music playing in the background.  Very friendly and welcoming staff (I can't remember her name) but she took the time to chat with us for a while and getting to know us.  Never have I experienced such attention.  My only disappointment was they ran out of pasteles (my favorite) and flan.  No worries.  I'll be back!  You will not be disappointed!
author: Marilyn O.

description:
It's so hard to find Cuban/PR cuisine on this coast, I'm glad i can turn to El Nuevo Frutilandia when I'm feeling like some home cooking. I hadn't been here in a minute, but happily stumbled on it after celebrating Day of the Dead. 

Our table of three especially loved the sangria (great deal by the carafe), the creamy, savory beans, and the unbelievably tender pork loin. Prices are moderate for San Francisco. Bonus: the service is super friendly; the owner and his wife are total sweethearts!
author: Felicia B.

description:
Even though there has been a cafe of one kind or another in this space for over three decades, it wasn't until I passed by during the recent Sunday Streets event that I happen to notice there are new owners who now serve Cuban and Puerto Rican cuisine. That's great news in a city seriously bereft of it. There's Paladar on Kearny, but they don't serve hot food after 3PM. There's Chan Chan west of the Castro - which I've never tried - but am a bit wary because of their constant Groupon deals. There was Charanga in the Mission and Laurel's in Hayes Valley, but both quietly closed. I didn't realize I missed them until they were gone. Gee, I sound like Joni Mitchell. Cuban, when done wrong, can get pretty greasy, a calorific nightmare, but when done right, I've liked it a lot like at the late, lamented Charanga.

Maybe Cuban food is too rarefied to catch on here, but owners Rafael and Tyrisha Frias and their chef Gary Millar are certainly putting their best foot forward in this space. From my recent solo dining experience there, the results are promising. I started with a house specialty, the $4.50 small bowl of Chicken Soup (Sopa de Pollo) which was definitely chock full of vegetables, a bit disintegrated from probably being in the pot for a while. There was also a tad too much oil in the broth since I noticed bubbles, but the soup was hot and flavorful with plenty of shards of chicken to satisfy and pepper sauce on the side for an optional extra kick (see photo). For my entree, I happened to be there on a Wednesday, so I took advantage of the daily special, the $12.25 Arroz con Pollo.

That was a nice plate of chicken pieces cooked with sauteed peppers and onions, and lots of spices. The saffron rice, which I assumed was cooked with the chicken, was especially delicious when mixed with the black beans (see photo). Satisfying home cooking for sure, although I was hoping the chicken parts were a bit bigger than they were, just my preference. It's a nice casual place, sadly not that busy, and the owners are quite friendly. Rafael is from Mexico, but he, his wife and Millar appear to have a sure hand in preparing and presenting these dishes. The $5 Yelp deal was definitely a good move, though they may want to up the amount like Arabian Nights does if they want to bring in more new business. Some trova musicians could liven the place up, too. I'll be back when I feel like a touch of Habana in my soul.

FOOD - 4 stars...solid home cooking, Cuban style, just needs a tad more refinement
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...pretty low key, maybe a bit more music from the Buena Vista Social Club could help
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...really friendly and attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...I liked it and I think Ricky Ricardo would, too
author: Ed U.

description: Well lucky was on my side bevause i was able to be seated right away. I only ordered tapas and a caraf of sangria(which was sooooo good). Their tapas were  small portions, but packed with great flavor! I'm still dreaming about their flan and tres leche cake. I will definitely return and try their entrees menu. You can't go wrong with delicious food and great service.
author: elena g.

description: Jasmine is a shining star. Coolest waitress ever. Keep your eyes peeled cause this little gem is easy to miss, but once you're inside the food is delicious, and very reasonably priced. The service was impeccable. The atmosphere is great too, some good tunes in the background, well decorated. You can't go wrong with this place!
author: Alex A.

description:
The shrimp mofongo is fantastic. Good selection of beers. Very reasonable prices. Our server Jasmine was fun and took great care of our table. We would definitely come back!

Not very crowded or noisy which is a plus. But great ambiance and nice Cuban music.
author: Tom P.

description: For a Cuban living in Santa Cruz the trip to the city for this was way worth it.  Had some tostones and yuca frita. Both were great. Finished off with a Vaca Frita with white rice and black beans that brought back some memories of Miami. It's a small location but highly recommend it to all.
author: Ruben R.

description: I travel to San Francisco quite a bit for work and I am always looking for new places to try.  I went to this place for the first time two weeks ago because I was in the mood for Cuban.  It's in the Mission/Latin Cultural District.  The staff and the owner were so welcoming and friendly it was like visiting friends.  It is by no means a big or fancy place but the food was solid.  I had the yucca and veggie empanada as starters.  I love yucca and it's hard to find a restaurant that gets it right.  The yucca here was perfectly fried and came with a nice sauce for dipping.  The empanada was also tasty and the crust was near perfection. It also came with a good sauce. I mixed it with the yucca sauce and the combo of the two was even better.  I split the ropa vieja with my dining companion. It was well cooked and with a little hot sauce spritz quite tasty.  Oh and don't pass on the sangria. I liked it because it was a nice fruity compliment to the food and not too much for me since I don't frequently drink.  I definitely plan to eat here again on my next trip to SF.
author: Oni B.

description: The mofongo was excellent. Only wish I had more room to try all their great plates. Small little place that paks a punch with the best type food in the bay area. WOW and at very reasonable prices
author: AL P.

description: Came on a Saturday for lunch. Atmosphere was casual and relaxed. Our waitress/hostess was very polite, but the relaxed atmosphere infiltrated the wait time on our food. We ordered the Cubanos and a side of baked beans. The Cubanos was good, buuutt a bit on the salty side. The ham was already salty and then to add a pickle threw it way over the top. The chips that the sandwich came with were very good...And so we're the beans. I would definitely come back (and have a big glass of water to go with it) but I won't be running back.
author: Kris Marie D.

description:
WORST Service EVER!! It took 45min for my Plantains to come...another 15 minutes for the main dishes..Seriously an hour to serve 3 items.. 1 dish, Cuban Sandwich, and Bananas...  

I expressed my concerns with the owner and in response she said "Well you walked in and saw all these people sitting" Seriously..thats an owners response? Wow!! there was a good 15 people..and a few empty seats..and ok..since they are"so" busy..  obviously they can not handle their client load. 

My response "I understand, BUT.. if you knew you were behind and OVERWHELMED..you should NOTIFY the customer, had I known Id be waiting damn near an hour  for a skimpy $16 shrimp dish, bland cuban sandwich and bananas, I would have taken my businesses  elsewhere" yet...she wanted to debate and again make it out to be my fault since I walked in to people already sitting there..waiting

What an experience..and Yes...I did say 45 min wait for platanos without the crema..SMH!! I will NEVER go here again!!
author: Jen L.

description: Great little find in the Mission for great Cuban food! Friendly service, great vibe and very clean!
author: Garret M.

description: Service is slow, server did not greet our table or take our order until 15+ minutes later. I went on a Sunday there was hardly anybody in the restaurant. The mofongo is awesome, chicken empanadas is crispy with a light dressing on the side. The arroz condule rice is dry.
author: Arasi H.

description:
Ignore the overall low star score! I don't review on Yelp often, but when I saw my favorite Cuban restaurant wasn't at 5 stars (or even 4) on here, I had to speak up! 

Ridiculously good, fresh and authentic Cuban food. I've been coming to this secret Mission gem for years; now that they've changed management and menu, it's even better. I have the garlic and lemon shrimp every time. Perfection!
author: L E.

description: Must have mofongo! Exceptional, tender pieces of pork underneath it all, just the right hint of garlic, I was throughly satisfied, quite comparable to the mofongo on the island! Staff was attentive and friendly, and Rafael and Jorge were kind enough to let me see how the magic is all done "All you gotta do is ask!" Warm and friendly, colorful environment, reminded me of Puerto Rican hospitality
author: Oscar A.

description:
Very good food. Mofongo is more than recommended, as well as plantain chips (just make sure they're not included in your main dish as a side, we didn't know so basically we had them twice). The only negative thing is that the portions are too small for their prices.

The service was amazing, both the waitresses were unbelievably kind.

Note: we went there on a Friday with a groupon, but they don't accept it that day of the week...
author: Xavier R.

description:
I feel like there is a dearth of Cuban restaurants in the neighborhood, so was interested to give this a try.

Everything was delicious and definitely recommend getting the sangria to go with.
author: Steven W.

description:
Loved this place! My first Cuban food and I'm super impressed!! :)

It is a little restaurant with super yummy food!!

The service is good too. 

I wish I could write more but I don't know any of the food names I ate haha but everything is awesome! I tried a lot of different things. :)
author: Peach K.

description: I have always loved this place.  It is totally laid back.  Nothing fancy, no pretensions, just nice people and great food.   This place is totally my style so I am biased.  I am not the new look that is destroying the Mission.  All the new restaurants are trying to be all upscale with small, expensive plates and reclaimed wood siding.  El Nuevo Fruitlandia is no frills, straight forward great food, great service, and good prices.  I hope that this place survives the gentrification of the Mission.
author: Christopher A.

description: Amazing food. Reminded me of my visit to Puerto Rico. The staff was so courteous, ambiance is great, food is delectable. Highly recommend the lechon horneado. I wish this place was closer to my hometown so I could  eat here more frequently.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Authentic Cuban food. One of the best meals I've ever had. So many subtle flavors. Every dish is mind blowing. Loved it.

Try the Mofongo. So good.
author: Harrison K.

description: This is one of my favorite places to eat at when I visit the Bay area.  They make excellent Mofongo which is very hard to find.  The owners are very friendly and told me they are locals to the neighborhood.  The food is so good, Guy Fieri even highlighted them on his Food Network show.  I HIGHLY recommend them.
author: Joseph M.

description: In south San Francisco for business, I ventured to explore what the city has to offer. I walked by Frutilandia as I was checking out 24th street restaurants. Checked out their menu and they had me at sangria y platanos maduros (plantains). Ordered ropa vieja after my red sangria. Sangria is delicious. I could have had maybe 2 more after my third one. Ropa vieja was very good accompanied with my fried platanos. Yum! The owner Rafeal introduced himself & made me feel more welcome in his restaurants. It was like being at a friends house. This place is worth checking out because I'm definitely going to frequent when in the city. Hasta pronto Rafa!
author: Ozzy T.

description: I called in a pick up order around 8pm. When I got home I saw that they added cheese to my salad when I requested no cheese and they forgot one of my main dishes and they changed me for it. I kept calling during business hours but they didn't answer. I will be calling again in the morning but only for a refund. The food was no where near as good as Los Cubanos in San Jose. Bad service. Mediocre food.
author: R. L.

description: I found this in Yelp... And Awesome service and great food, definitely a plus. I felt "Home". Also 10 % off my tab... Nice!!!!
author: Ernesto S.

description:
My boyfriend and I were always passing this place so I jumped on the Groupon deal they had! Came for lunch and we were super disappointed their lasagna special was taken off the menu! They apparently had just revamped their menus and took it off. Total bummer since thats what we were most looking forward to!

We ended up getting the vegetarian mofongo and he got this spicy shrimp dish. Both came with black beans and rice. The rice was surprisingly seasoned but the beans weren't! I usually like beans but I thought theirs tasted awful so my boyfriend ate all of them. 

The mofongo was a delicious! I ate the whole thing and the portion was huge! You HAVE to try it with their house made sauce. It totally makes the dish! One odd thing was the mofongo was different temperatures all around making me think it was reheated in the microwave or something. The shrimp on the other hand came piping hot with a really tasty sauce! 

Service was super nice and the decor is super cute!!! I felt like I was on vacation or something haha. Definitely fun to try out a place we've been curious about but will not return to.
author: Tiffany V.

description: They were featured on Food network and wanted to try their food for awhile. I finally did and ordered mofongo w/ pork and salad with guava sauce for take-out. While waiting, ordered a guanabana drink. All great tasting, will definitely come back here again.
author: Miel M.

description: Veryyyyy gooooood food must go. Especially if u want some old fashion tropical Latin food.
author: Nubia G.

description: I saw this restaurant featured on Guy Fieri's show, so I thought I'd take a chance and order the ropa vieja. I was not disappointed: it lived up to to its excellent reviews and exceeded all expectations. I wanted another serving when I was finished. The inside of the restaurant is very welcoming, the female owner greeted me with a big smile, and the music playing in the background makes this the perfect place for lunch, dinner, brunch, whatever. These are good people serving excellent home-cooked Cuban/Puerto Rican food. You will not leave hungry.
author: Maurice R.

description: Bought a Groupon for this place. Pretty good food, I enjoyed. I got the mofongo, ceviche and my sister got the chicken.. we also ordered the white sangria which was amazingggg! Small restaurant, had the Salsa music going and the ladies were attentive. We sat at the bar, so it was nice. I def plan to go back.
author: Katherine R.

description:
I've only had Puerto Rican food in the Bay Area and Miami, and out of all the local restaurants, this one is the most legit. I've never seen it on the Food Network or Check Please, or written up in the Chronicle, and perhaps that's why it's so charming. This is a small restaurant that is easy to miss as you look for parking! 

The food is amazing. It's beautiful without being too structured. Very good portion sizes and authentic flavor. The prices are a good value. I'm not exactly thrilled by the daily specials, because I always want a special that isn't offered on the day I choose to come here! But hey, that's not their fault. 

The decor feels home-y and the ambiance is warm and inviting, though not quiet if that's what you're looking for. I'm so glad that after all these years, I can still rely on great Puerto Rican food in my hometown. It's hard to find a fellow Puerto Rican out here, let alone a restaurant serving our food!
author: Jennifer P.

description:
So my cousins and I came here thanks to a groupon offer. 

Pros:
The batidos (milkshakes) are delicious
The bistec empanisado is delicious
Cute restaurant
The music makes me want to dance 

Cons:
We waited a long time ... only cause the joint is understaffed. However, the service was very friendly! So half con.
The beans...sigh. I'm cuban, I like my beans to be spicy and delicious like they should be. Pero, no go.
It's more Puerto Rican than Cuban. Enough said

Overall, check it out! :) ...I'm probably biased since I'm cuban.
author: Carina M.

description:
My girlfriend wanted me to try some puerto rican/ cuban food so we decided to come here since we were in the area.

It was a sunday night after 8, but they still let us come in.

It took us a while to decide and I ended up ordering the vegetarian mofongo and she ordered chicken empanadas, arroz con gandules, and platanos maduros. We ordered the mate soda and finished off with café con leche.

Considering I am vegetarian I could only try the platanos and they were pretty good. But let me tell you...I eat A LOT of food and the vegetarian mofongo has been the best thing I have eaten so far! I have never tried this dish before and it blew my mind. The vegetable filled mashed fried plaintain dish was topped with this creamy garlic sauce and served with white rice and beans. The crispy/crunchy/ soft combination of textures of the mofongo and the burst of flavor from the sauce gave me a mouthgasm. Even the rice tasted fantastic and was textured perfectly.
