The service was phenomenal. The owner came over to chat and was super friendly! He gave us some background information on the restaurant and explained to us the food we ordered. The waitress was friendly, patient, and helpful with us ordering.

Hands down the best food and service I have experienced. I will be coming back here again for sure!
author: Stephanie L.

description:
The beans did not have any flavor,  the pernil was ok, but did not have that authentic Puerto Rican flavor.
The tostones were decent. 

The alcapurrias were burned, but still tasted ok, but why would you serve your customers burnt food,

I ate at this restaurant a few years ago and the food was a lot better. 

I was very disappointed,  I spent over $100 and threw away most of the food (ordered the food to go).
author: Daniel S.

description:
This spot is a must to visit when you're around the Mission.
The Cubano sandwich with extra mustard will be forever my favorite... or is it the Alcapurrias... or maybe the Ropa Vieja, I JUST LOVE IT ALL!! 

When my boyfriend and I go here.. he always has to order a Sangria.
This place is awesome for a modern mom and pop type of restaurant.
author: Chelsey B.

description:
Sorry to report: El Nuevo Frutilandia is not even mediocre food at best.  

Unfortunately,  I struggled giving this spot 2 stars. Came here for dinner on 11-25-12; I ordered the Puerto Rico sandwich which was bland and they skimped me on the steak meat (see pics). Also, the fries that came with the my meal were loaded with so much grease they shined.

My wife ordered the Spinach empanada con queso (1 of 3 veggie options). Ten minutes into our wait, our server informs us they are out of empanadas- grrr.  The server then recommended the only other vegetarian options which were the chili relleno or mofongo vegetariano. Since my toddler son was sharing the plate we opted with the mofongo vegetariano (consisting of plaintains, rice, beans). 

My sandwich came soon after we got my wife's order straightened out which left me in a small dilemna.  Either let my food get cold waiting for my wife's meal or chow down in front of her. Our server saw my hesitation and informed me that I should eat since her meal would be a while. 

As I am munching down on my Puerto Rico sandwich, I realize my sandwich looks nothing like the pics on Yelp and how terrible it tastes. With each bite of my sandwich I taste more bread and lettuce than any meat.  Where is all the savory meat? Did they run out of this also? I decide to take inventory, so I open my sandwich to reveal less than six strips of steak meat (see pic). and for over $10. Verdict: F-

The second entree (mofongo vegetariano) eventually arrives and that also is not met with satisfaction-- not much flavor, small portions.  

But a huge plus is in order for the house made sangria (white wine) which I was looking forward to (1st star).  However I was craving a red wine sangria but the white wine sangria was pretty awesome served mixed with apple, orange, lemon slices, etc (see pic). But at $6 a glass... well let's just say, they can do better. 

Space is tight in this restaurant.  My little boy wouldn't sit still and without the availability of a high chair (the only other one was occupied), he had to eat on our lap during dinner.  Tip: Be prepared to wait.  Usually, I am pretty patient when it comes to wait times, but I did observe the couple next to us grow frustrated from the wait, and finally they paid and left without the food they ordered. 

In terms of ambiance/vibe, there was Latin music playing, but with all the yelling and clamor from within the kitchen and amongst staff, it made it hard to have a conversation at the dinner table.

Maybe I came on an off night, but with so many choices in the area, I cannot see myself returning or recommending this spot.
 
The deal (2nd star): Used a groupon deal I purchased for $20 that got me two sangria drinks and two entrees.  

(+) Latin music playing
(-) long wait for dinner
(-) cramped restaurant
(-) limited veggie options
(- -) My Puerto Rico Sandwich was a huge disappointment.  It lacked meat and flavor (see pics).
author: Denis A.

description:
My roommate and I came here around 9 PM on a Saturday night (they close at 10 on sat) and about 1/3rd of the restaurant was full. It's a little hidden gem off of 24th that I've had bookmarked for a while and I'm so glad we finally went. 
 The ambiance is very San Juan and colorful, the whole place is really cute. I'm vegetarian, and everything on the menu sounded amazing to me. Puerto Rican restaurants hardly offer vegetarian dishes, and this place had tons of options. I ordered the mofongo vegetariano, plaintanos meduros, and a side of white rice and black beans. My roommate had the buttermilk chicken and ate ever last bite. All of the portions are decent sized and the plates are put together beautifully. 
The food was amazing. 10000 times better than any other Puerto Rican restaurants in the Bay Area (except for a certain sol food in San Rafael). The service was meh, but the food trumped all. We ate every last bite. 
After we paid, the chef came out to our table to introduce himself and ask how we liked the food. He said to ask for anything vegetarian next time and he'll do it (;
author: Emma G.

description: I had the Saturday daily special and the food did not live up to the hype. The food was over priced with very small portions. I did not like my rice or my chicken. I ordered from Yelp so I did not have much interaction with the staff. I would not return to this establishment.
author: Dee F.

description:
My first-ever visit, 1:30pm Saturday lunchtime. Prompt, friendly service, from start to finish. Still, the food was the real star of this experience. Even my own homemade-from-scratch chicken soup can't hold a candle to their delicious chicken soup. It really is a don't-miss.

I was tempted by the Saturday special, but decided to risk fish, which is so hard to get right and so easy to get wrong. Am I glad I went for it! I ordered Filete De Pargo-- red snapper fillet sauteed in olive oil, garlic, lemon and parsley.  It was the best fish dish I've had in years; delicate, moist, skinless, perfect done-ness. The olive oil, garlic, lemon and parsley were so subtle as to allow the fresh fish itself to shine. Yum. 

It came with a large-ish plate of al dente black beans and steamed white rice, again allowed to shine in subtlety and simplicity.

I'm not familiar with Puerto Rican or Cuban cuisines, so can't draw comparisons with other chefs, or with this same restaurant under previous ownership. Today's food was so spectacular and reasonably priced that I will be back. I'm glad that the new (7 months, he said) owners decided to take it over, to keep the restaurant open.

The restaurant is tiny, with very "live" acoustics, so not so easy to carry on a conversation; one happy family with lots of laughter pretty-much dominated the soundscape during my meal. Family-friendly. Clean little restroom.

I asked how the restaurant got its name. He said it began as a fruit smoothies shop. I'd been expecting a more exotic explanation. LOL!
author: Ari T.

description:
I have been going to El Nuevo Fruitilandia for about 25 years! When it was kind of a dive, but great food. When I moved into the neighborhood. Yes, it's been around that long. Shows how old I am! I haven't been there in a couple of years. So I took my niece - her first time to El Nuevo Fruitilandia. As much as I love this restaurant, when operated by the former owners, I really believe the new owners have tweaked some dishes, making them just as good or better. And added some new dishes and appetizers on the menu.

My niece and I went mostly for appetizers (tapas). We ordered (2) papa rellena, mofongo, alcapurrias, empanadas, and the appetizer combo (tostones, yucca con mojo, platanos maduros). And another appetizer like a tamal, Puerto Rican version. Made with plantains/platanos, tara root, and more! We ordered one main dish we shared - paella. We both ordered tropical smoothie drinks. Like smooth tropical milkshakes. Made with Caribbean tropical fruits. I'm lactose intolerant, so I ditched the milk, and replaced with water. Still so good. All that was mentioned, you're going to have to cross-reference the menu to the pics posted on Yelp! to see the actual plates.

Did I eat everything we ordered? I could have! But I just wanted to sample and gave the rest to my niece to take home.

The decor hasn't changed much since the last owners' remodel. Actually, some of the same wall decor from the very orignal restaurant, 25 years ago. The restaurant is clean and quaint. They no longer have a guitar player in the front window area, like they used to on Friday and Saturday nights. Would be nice to have. The waiter/server was very friendly and helpful.  We ate lunch when they opened. I know dinner must get crowded.

El Nuevo Fruitilandia is an even more special place to dine for me. If you want to try Puerto Rican-Cuban cuisine, El Nuevo Fruitilandia stands out! I give them a high-5 rating! They compete well with all the new restaurants on lower 24th St (Calle 24/Veinticuatro). I think they surpass a lot of the newer trendy places. And it still has the flavor of the Mission heritage. El Nuevo Fruitilandia has been there longer than folks know. And I hope it will be there for many more years!

I showed my Yelp! coupon on my smartphone and got the discount. That paid for an appetizer+. So don't forget to mention and show when your first order. And check if they're Groupon-friendly too.
author: Roger S.

description: This is a cozy and casual restaurant in Mission serving Cuban and Puerto Rican meal. My server was Raven and she was very friendly, attentive and provided some great suggestions for drinks and food. I had the veggie Mofongo and it was really good. Very authentic and filling. I will be going back to try other items on the menu. Was very reasonable as well. Under $20 for a drink and meal is a great deal IMO.
author: Milesh J.

description:
This reminded me of the food I had in Cuba- bland!! We have been coming to Fruitlandia on and off for 20+ years and have usually had great experiences here
I LOVE Cuban and Puerto Rican food but this place no longer does it justice at all. The ropa vieja looked like ropa vieja but tasted like salpicon (a very bland version of salpicon). The Cubano sandwich had a slightly sweet but still kind of bland pulled pork in it. WTF? You can't just switch out the roasted pork and still call it a Cubano! On top of that the bread was either stale or over cooked. The maduro had a very strange flavor. How can you mess up fried plantain? On the positive side, service was nice and the habichuelas were good. As i said, I frequented this establishment for 20+ years. We had a great run but it's over now.
author: carol c.

description: The food was truly authentic! I loved the mofongo and I was also seriously impressed with the sautéed shrimp and arroz con gandules. I HIGHLY recommend this quaint but wonderful little restaurant!!!
author: DeAnna J.

description:
I give this place one star based on expectations. I haven't actually had any food at El Nuevo Fruitlandia because I bought a groupon hoping I could use it. I should have read the fine print because the first time I went to the restaurant to use my groupon I was told I could not because it was Friday.  Understandable if they were very busy, but it was 5pm and the joint was empty. They could have made an exception. 

When we left it would have been nice if the waiter had said something to the effect of 'oh, and we are also not open on Tuesdays'. But no such luck.

Nor did I have luck trying the food going to El Nuevo Fruitlandia on a Tuesday. Closed.

So, lesson learned. Don't expect a restaurant to be open on a Tuesday and don't expect to be given full information by staff. 

Frustrated.
author: Luis M.

description:
If I had a Puerto Rican grandma, I would like to think this is the comforting, no frills fare that she would be slinging out of her kitchen. 

Food: 

Perfect to satisfy a craving. Went on a Saturday and had the special, which was a shredded pork with rice and beans. The rice and beans were perfect. Rice was fluffy, lightly seasoned, it was hard to stop myself and eat the the rest. Beans were great, I am 90% sure they had meat in them, which in my mind, was awesome. Pulled pork could have been a little juicier, but that's just being nit picky. 

Ceviche was good but not amazing. Portion was a little small, and the cabbage could of been shredded better. 

Plantains were delicious, I wanted to stuff some in my pockets for later. 

Service: 

Attentive and relaxed


Pro tip: check in on yelp, we got 15% off. Also, if your a vegetarian, check the sides for meat just in case. See beans above.
author: Patrick T.

description: Very good Cuban & Puerto Rican food and warm, friendly service and atmosphere! Saturday Lechon special was great as was picadillo, chicken & beef empanadas and mango sangria! We'll definitely be back!
author: Angelique V.

description: We recently met a group of friends at El Nuevo Fruitlandia for an early dinner. There were 6 of us and we all had eaten here before it changed hands. The old Fruitlandia served Salvadorian food and it was very good. Now it features Cuban and Puerto Rican food. Where the old restaurant was kind of funky the way it was decorated and it has changed a little. I noticed the photo of my Wife in her head dress costume for Carnaval was missing from the wall. She is pretty attractive so maybe someone wanted a memento of the Carnaval parade?  I ordered a Cuban sandwich and my Wife ordered the Mofongo . We also had lots of plantains/platanos. The food was pretty good and the pepper infused vinegar on the table went well on my sandwich. Overall we though the food was good, but just a little pricey
author: Bruce S.

description:
Delicious! 

Went here last weekend (incidentally, with Patrick T. who left the previous review). I think we all had the "Saturday Special" which was awesome. I can't eat spicy food so I love that this place is flavorful but not spicy. Make sure you get a side of the sweet plantains, you won't be disappointed.
author: Amy G.

description:
GF and I stopped by for lunch on Saturday.  The food was fine - I thought the maduros were really good.  Nice caramelization. 

The only thing off was the service, which was slow.  Not sure if it was the waitress, who was handling all of the tables, or the kitchen, but it took a long time for the food to come out.  I'd guess it was close to 1 hour from sitting down, ordering and then getting our entrees.  

I'd probably come back but this would depend on how full the dining room was.
author: Larry L.

description: Damn, what a joy it is to have another Caribbean joint to go to in SF. The shortage of Caribbean and South American food in San Francisco always drives me crazy and Frutilandia capably fills a giant void. Before you balk, let me clarify, Mexico is in North America and El Salvador is in Central America and the cuisine in both is very different from what is common in other regions of Latin America. The only other Caribbean spot in the city that is as authentic being Parada 22. Frutilandia is Caribbean in multiple ways, one of them being that the place is very casual and unrushed, you never feel like you are expected to eat and leave. The emapanadas here are perfectly done, perfect texture and flavor. The lechon horneado (oven roasted pork) is incredibly flavorful and juicy. I highly recommend having a side of yuca with your entree. Be aware, the sangria here is very sweet and fruity which is exactly how I prefer it. There are so many items on the menu I've yet to try that I'm always giddy when I find myself in the area so I can have a new adventure.
author: Paolo R.

description:
Excellent food! Almost as good as my grandmothers. Service was great! Love the music & atmosphere. Wish we got a little more food for the price but can't really complain cause it really authentic. You can tell they put a lot of pride into their food.
Pros:- They serve Malta
         - Sangria, Mmm
         -Alcapurria outstanding.
         -Real Puerto Rican Owners & staff!

Cons: -Wish the servings were a little bigger.

We will definitely return. If your looking for authentic Puerto Rican food this is the place!
author: Raquel Q.

description: Cute restaurant...we had the same photo of a house in Puerto Rico as they did! We ordered the tostones, mofongo, pastel for appetizers and for dinner we had the ropa vieja, pierna de puerco horneada...it was all delicious!! Make sure you ask for the Puerto Rican hot sauce...sorry we emptied the bottle. Order the flan con queso...it was so good...cheesy and worth it!!! We will be back...Can't wait.
author: hac h.

description:
Its home cooking but I think they need to get some fresh pans.  Boy.. you take a look inside the kitchen and it seems they haven't got fresh kitchen ware and utensils since the 1960s.   Also I kind of feel bad about how labor intensive the poor woman is like a slave cooking.

The food is however delicious and I always hope to return. They make perfect "plantains" Cuban style and mostly all their dishes have a remote Nicaraguan + Cuban mix to it.  

When you order, be more selective about how you are mixing various dishes together and share by having common plates (Chinese food style) with sides of extra rice - you will likely need it.   The same for the soups.. order a soup dish and then a meal dish and plan to share with your group.
author: Tito Y.

description: Great service! And delicious food! Back in the beginning of the year I had just moved out to SF from the Midwest and was really interested in trying food from different cultures. My boyfriend and I stumbled across fruitlandia when walking through the mission. I've heard that cubanos are really good and they happened to have it on their menu! So of course I ordered it, with a can of "Iron Beer" or Cuba cola. Both tasted delicious and we had visited again because we love the service and the food! We will for sure tell our families and friends of this place!
author: Ana C.

description: Food was wonderful, the service was wonderful and the people are great. Wait time was short and quick service.  Felt like I was part of the family.
author: Nicole L.

description:
This is an authentic Cuban and Puerto Rican, family run joint that has great food and friendly staff. The fruit shakes are AMAZING, the plantain appetizers are plentiful, and the pork dishes are tender and juicy. 
The only thing I'd comment on is the need for salt and spice. The pork definitely needed salt and the pepper vinegar on the table helped but didn't give the kick I wanted. Unfortunately, the only options on the table were Tapitio and Tobasco and I didn't want to mask the wonderful flavors with those. 
We will definitely come back for more shakes, apps, and to try the Cuban sandwich.
author: Ashley F.

description:
Oh My Goodness!  If you ever find yourself in the Mission/Market area, find this place!  We stopped by for dinner because we wanted a place to eat that was going to be near where our main attraction was.  We didn't want Mexican, again.  We have found scrumptious Mexican food in this same area, but we just wanted something a little bit different.
This place served it up!
Not only were the wait staff very friendly, when we pointed at the menu for lack of being able to pronounce what we wanted, we were given head nods and smiles.  Very warm and inviting.
We started with their house shake.  They let us combine fruits so we kind of got a custom shake.  This is a Batidos.  So creamy with finely crushed ice.  Perfect start since we were really thirsty.
Next our salad were brought to us.  Just a little cup of salad.  House dressing was different.  Nothing much to shout about here, but it was good and we ate all our vegetables.
Next came dinner.   We ordered Chile Rellenos and Filete de Pollo a la Española.  Some one in the kitchen was making MAGIC!  The sauce for the chicken dish was so good.  Good is not a strong enough word.  This dish was not spicy.  It was not chili hot.  But it was real down home comfort food.  Lots of chunks of chicken with a  side of white rice and a cup of black beans.   The Chile Rellenos was a work of art.  Perfect in every way.  We have found another favorite restaurant.  
The place is small.  But even on a Saturday night, we managed to get a table right away without a reservation.  It's old, we were told they have been there for 40 years.  But that's was so much of the charm.  I love these "hole in the wall" places that put the fancy schmancy restaurants to shame!
Don't dine in if you're in a hurry.  They must make everything to order so it takes a little bit to get your dinner.  It's so worth the wait.  If you must be somewhere and you're pressed for time, they do take out and  you can call ahead.  Check out their web site.  And GO!
author: Reba Jane S.

description: We love Puerto Rican food, with Husband having grown up with it and all. We can't find any place that serves mofongo near our home in Placer County, so when we are out of town we often look for a great place to get our "mofongo fix."  Husband likes his very traditional, with pork, so this place was perfect. It serves it with pork or vegetarian. I prefer it with chicken, but the pork was very tender and, after all it IS the "other" white meat, so I can live with pork just fine. The ground beef empanadas and papa rellenas (mashed potatoes with a bit of ground beef deep fried together) also happen to be a couple of our favorites, and they were done well. We were very happy to see that they were served with the Thousand Island type sauce also known as "pink mayo" that is the perfect complement to both these tapas. It is the mofongo that you really need to come here for, though. It is not easy to find and it is so delicious!
author: Joanna M.

description: probably my favorite PR joint in the city. always solid, nothing fancy, just great food.
author: W R.

description:
My husband and I wandered in here because Yelp had a check-in-offer for 15% off our bill ;) We ordered Mofongo and the Ropa Vieja because they are classic Puerto Rican dishes and could serve as a sort of control group. The Mofongo came out a very small portion, molded on the plate in the shape of a dome with a (kinda stale) plantain chip sticking out. It was very good, we thoroughly enjoyed it but it was gone in 4 bites. The really surprising thing was that the Ropa Vieja was even skimpier. It was on a plate that you would expect to hold a side dinner salad. It had a tiny scoop of white rice, a tiny cup of black beans and a tiny scoop of meat. Both plates together would barely have even been enough to feed one hungry person. We were one hungry person and one filled-up-on-Phil'z person and it was nowhere near enough food. 
The server was so nice and we tipped him very generously, of course based on our pre-discounted total and he seemed very grateful. Unfortunately we will not return though because in order to fill our appetites we would need to spend about $40 and ain't nobody got time for that at lunchtime.
author: Emma H.

description: Came here to use my groupon at 4:00 (said that's what the opening time was) and was not open. Lady said they would be opening ten mins later. Came back 45 mins later and they were still closed. Bad business, no wonder why they have to offer groupons and discounts on yelp to convince people to come in.
author: Yung C.

description: Boriqua and Cuban food is so delicious here. A very small restaurant; however the food speaks for itself. Slightly pricey but all things great are worth paying for. I left this place in pure satisfaction. The tostones drenched in garlic were definitely my favorite.
author: Ruth B.

description:
After a friend raved about a restaurant in Miami that served amazing Mofongo, I went on a mission to find a restaurant in California that served it. Surprisingly, this proved to be more difficult than I originally thought.

So while I was on a trip to San Francisco I paid a visit to El Nuevo Frutilandia in the Mission District for their Mofongo. I ordered the Vegetarian Mofongo (which on their menu is only listed as an entree with sides, but our server let us order it a la carte as the appetizer). Granted, this was my first experience with Mofongo, so I have nothing to compare it to, but I wasn't overly impressed. I didn't think it tasted like it had too much garlic, but to be honest, my sister and I suffered the remainder of the night with awful garlic breath (sorry for the overshare, but if you come here on a date, best to avoid the Mofongo). 

We also ordered the pulled pork entree. It was good, but the surprising standout was the Sopa de Pollo that came as the side. There were big chunks of chicken and vegetables. If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd come by here and get a bowl every time I was craving something warm, healthy, comfort food.
author: Brianna M.

description:
I am eating here right this moment!  Holy moly this half Puerto Rican is pleased.  Reminds me if mi abuelas cooking.  New favorite spot in the city for Caribbean fair.

Vaca Frita is amazing!  Order it!  Do it!  I am also loving my guava shake.
author: Christopher C.

description:
Unfortunately, that place didn't work well for us. We went there around 4 o'clock on Sunday , but they already "run out" of iced tea. Restaurant was empty.
Beans were overcooked , ceviche looked like a plate of onions sprinkled with oil, we had to return it, but the waitress was very nice and she took that dish without any problems. Empanadas were good, service was nice , but it is not worth to go back
author: Yulia M.

description: Friendly staff and delicious dinner. Who knew this place has been here for 40 years?!  Go support this family business. Seriously.
author: Jonathan J.

description:
Came here on a Friday night in June, wasn't busy so we were seated right away. It's not a large restaurant but has a great atmosphere for an intimate meal for 2 or laughs and drinks with friends. Nice music playing in the background. 

Ordered our food, and within 10 minutes our food was being served to us. Didn't expect such speedy service, a definite plus. The presentation of both meals were nice and the red wine Sangria was amazing. 

The carnitas plate I ordered was seasoned well and the black beans were some of the best I've ever had. 

Good place to try if you're looking for a tasty meal and great Sangria.
author: Jarrett D.

description: Vaca Frita was really fantastic.  The sweet plaintains are very good. Great service too.
author: April M.

description:
The food,? excellent, the service? Wonderful the mango sangria? AMAZING!!!!! 
One of the best  puertorican food ever! 
And I can said that because I'm 100%puertorican!   

Great job and thanks for a great service!
author: Omar M.

description:
I love this place!
I've always gone with my kids during lunch or early dinner. This restaurant is very family friendly. 
The ceviche is amazing! Always get this. 
I've had various items on the menu and have never been disappointed. The staff are always helpful at providing advice if you can't decide.
author: Bob M.

description: They were at SFSFF 2013. I had the cubano sandwich. It was good but the ham on it looked liked lunch meat from the grocery store...
author: Alexys E.

description:
This place is awesome!  Super tasty and the servers are really nice.  I had the vaca frita and it was incredible!!!  

Also their passion fruit is superb.

Was totally surprised with how good everything was.  From the beans to the salad to the empanadas. 

Overall amazing!!
author: Spencer L.

description:
Honestly, I really wanted to like this place as it is a cute little restaurant a few blocks from my place.  

The service is great, but the food was horrible.  Literally one of the worst meals I have had all year.   The rice was old and so crunchy it hurt my gums. We ordered the Ropa Vieja and it was cold and icky.  We also got the shrimp in garlic butter sauce and it was flavorless and not cooked all the way.   The best thing we ate were the fried plantains and the black beans.  I was a little worried I might get sick from the food, but ended up being fine.

Not only was the food terrible, but it was really expensive!  Almost $40 for two people and no alcohol.
author: Christine N.

description: I simply love Puerto Rican food, especially at El Nuevo Frutilandia. It's my secret place but I have been telling so many people about it lately that it ended up on a friend's blog today. Check it out the blog at: http://isthisfrisco.tumblr.com/post/109207201104/day-26-frutilandia-cuban-puerto-rican and don't forget to go in for some delicious food and a warm welcome.
author: Mikael B.

description:
The only reason I know of El Nuevo Frutilandia is because my friend lives just a couple of blocks from there. I was able to find the restaurant using the Yelp app and reading that it's a Latin American restaurant I was pretty excited to eat there. 

It's not in the best of neighborhoods and it's surrounded by Mexican restaurants and liquor stores. Parking is hard to find but then again parking is always hard to find in San Francisco. From the outside the place doesn't look very appealing but on the inside it's a very quaint restaurant.

I ordered the Cubano, which is their Cuban sandwich that consists of pork and ham. The sandwich was good but the presentation was awful. It looked as if the sandwich was made as if the cook was given a time limit. Just an awful mess and the fries were just as bad as they were soggy. 

On your very first check in you will be given a Yelp deal that gives you 25% off your order. That's a plus given that I wasn't thrilled about the look of the sandwich and the fries were bad. Just make sure that when you check in and the Yelp offer appears to let your server know right away, as there is a time limit. 

The staff was very accommodating. Both the manager and the waiter were nice and easy to talk to. The bottom line is this. If you happen to be in this neighborhood that is surrounded by countless of taquerias and Mexican restaurants and you want to try something different then I recommend this place. Otherwise I'm sure you can find plenty of other Latin American restaurants.
author: Yong Jae C.

description: Just had dinner at this place and it was great!  Being from Miami and visiting our son who lives on SF, we needed our usual Friday night fix for Cuban food.  Man, this place was great, however a limited menu, which is understandable  being so far from Miami and south.  The service was very good and the owner was very friendly.   We ordered a lot of traditional foods, tostones, fried plantains, ropa veiha, picadillo, Vaca frita, and rice and black beans and finished with flan, which was home made by the owners wife.  It was fantastic.   I highly recommend this place if you need your Cubano craving.  Definitely will return when visiting SF again, which is frequently.
author: Barbara P.

description:
We tried El Neuvo Fruitlandia for the first time today because we'd been looking for a place to get ropa vieja. They have it as an empanada, a sandwich, or an entree.

We got the Ropa vieja empanadas (crispy outside, meaty inside, with nicely cooked red peppers), the Empanadas del Espinacas (ala carte), the Plàtanos Maduros (yes, fried plantains can be even better with a little butter and Kahlua), and the Papa Rellena (Mashed potatoes filled with nicely seasoned ground beef & green peppers, fried golden brown).

All tasty. Service was good. We plan to return to try some of the items we had to forgo this time.

Vegetarian entrees and appetizers available as well as beef, pork, and chicken.
author: Vicki B.

description:
Fun food, totally unpretentious setting and service.  Reasonable prices.  Generous portions.  Usually not hard to find street parking nearby.  Unusual take on ceviche (with pineapple - like refreshing beach food) and they are happy to offer the yucca steamed instead of fried (delicious - buttery and garlicky).

Great go-to spot for relaxed Cuban/Puerto Rican food.
author: Chase P.

description:
I really wanted to like you more, esp since I've had such good experiences with Puerto Rican food at Parada 22 and El Sol. But the service was soooo slow! There was one waitress for about 5 tables, and she was so inefficient, but sweet. And on the night we went, I guess the chef had ditched work to celebrate his birthday, and a burner was out, so the food came out super slow and the chicken soup was cold. aye dios mio

But the food was good: the tostones (friend plaintains) were fresh and crisp and accompanied by a savory garlic dip. The acalpurria (mashed plantains and yucca wrapped around ground beef) was an interesting little bite. The Picadillo A La Habana Vieja (cuban style ground sirloin beef cooked with olives, capers, raisins) was a wee bit too salty, but the side pink beans were bomb!

They just need to get their act together and they'll get more customers.
author: Susan H.

description: Best place around!  Great atmosphere and truly amicable staff.  Zakary is a true gentlemen and one of a kind. Great place for a date.
author: Matteo D.

description: Placed to go order online, was contacted 15 minutes later that the restaurant was closed, when their hours stated open. Didn't try any food! Get your stuff figured out.
author: Amanda M.

description: I had the Cuban Sandwich and Sangria.  Both were very good.  I recently learned while traveling in Cuba that Cuban don't eat Cuban Sandwiches (they eat rice, beans and pork mainly).  Oh well, I still like these sandwiches.  The service was friendly.  My friend and I shared an appetizer.  Reasonable prices, good food, good service.  I"ll be back.
author: Debbie W.

description: This place is insanely bomb. If you're an East Coast transplant looking for consistently good Puerto Rican/Cuban food, this be your spot.
author: Will F.

description:
I had a solid dinner here on Day of the Dead, after failing to get in other spots around 24th street.  I ordered a really healthy serving of ropa vieja, and my girlfriend ordered a similarly huge yucca dish.  I'd rate both dishes as good home cooking, but not great.

That being said -- the prices were reasonable, and service was courteous (not so much prompt, perhaps due to the heavy traffic on a weeknight).

I don't know if I'd go back, though, given alternatives in the neighborhood.
author: Bill H.

description:
My husband and I tried this place last night. We were greeted by a friendly woman,( I'm assuming she is the owner.) We ordered the tostone's, mmm. They had this delicious garlic lemon sauce and were salted just enough. We also shared the veggie mofongo tapa, which was heartier than expected and smothered in a delicious tomato sauce that was comforting, it had a taste from home. I also tried the mango sangria, I couldn't taste the mango, but the sangria was really refreshing. I had to have a second glass!
For our entree's: I had the Limon Ajo Camarones, I loved this dish. The flavor of the sauce was so good, lemony garlic and the prawns were cleaned and cooked just right! The rice and cuban black beans had a good flavor too. Great portion size. I was stuffed!
My husband enjoyed the Lechon Horneado. So flavorful and moist, also a great portion size.. If you like pork? This dish is absolutely amazing! I tasted it and it had so much flavor. 
We will definitely be going back! This place is a hidden gem. I never had even noticed it until I yelped Cuban food. The interior is really cute, and makes you feel like you are on a mini-vacay. Friendly people and service, and really fresh and tasty quality food!
author: Hope A.

description:
If you go at Lunch, you might want to consider ordering your food before you get there, if you don't mind rolling with Latin Time, or European luncheon hour you'll be just find.

I have yet to try their actual food, I just keep going back for their insanely delicious Cuban Sandwichs. Okay so the bread isn't that flacky yellow baguette you pick up in Miami at Publix or your local Farm Store, but who cares they load up this sucker with so much marinated amazing Pork (the most important part of the Cuban Wich) by the end you forget sandwiches come with bread. 

Oh the Mother land...hehehe anyways I will update my review once I go back for some Mofongo and Fricase de Pollo.
author: Lannette G.

description:
OK, so I've never had Cuban or Puerto Rican cusine, at least not that I can remember. I decided to play it safe, considering I don't like spicy or plantains and ordered the Camarones al Ajillo (prawns in lemon and garlic sauce). OMG, I was not disappointed, the garlic flavor was amazing and the prawns were cooked to profection. Where did my beans and rice go? Oh yeah, I ate them. Usually I don't like restaurant's black beens (never flavorful or tender enough), these left me looking for more. 

So what,  I'm here at work smelling like garlic, I don't care! I'm full and satisfied!

Don't like milk either, so my smoothy was made with orange juice it was so refreshing, not to hear "that's how we make our smoothies".

I wish I lived in the City today because I'd be right back there tonight to get some more of those beans and rice.

The staff is very friendly and attentive which makes for a four star establishment!
author: Carmen R.

description:
My coworkers were planning a big Cuban-themed party, and being responsible for the food, I looked into various Cuban and Puerto Rican places in SF who could possibly cater. Since Frutilandia is in my stomping grounds, I decided to go in one night and order a bunch of food to try. The beans, rice, steak sandwich, chicken, plantains, everything was so good and made with love. Oh, and their Sangria is awesome.

I asked if they could cater the party and the chef, Gary, was so into it. He was very collaborative, creative, and more than happy to work with my very meager budget. He made cubanos, plantains, roasted veggies, chimichurri chicken skewers, and black beans and rice. Everything was hot and ready on time. It was a hit.

Not only is the food delicious, but the people who own and operate this cozy little restaurant treat you like family. I'm almost scared to give them a five star review for fear that I'll have to wait an hour for a table now.

I'll definitely be back again and again, with all my friends and family.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I ordered the Pierna de Puerco Horneada and it was pretty tastey but lacked that down-home-abuela-made-it taste. I feel like maybe it's the 80s generation in the kitchen. It does have some soul to it but not 100%. I found the portions are too small for this style of restaurant. A $15 plate of rice, beans, and pork done right should be hard to finish, if not impossible. But I ordered on GrubHub, maybe that's why it was small? Anyway I picked it up, walked two blocks home, and when I got there most of the food was cold. It wasn't cold out either. I asked for pink beans but they were black. BUT I also picked it up 15 minutes before closing, so I didn't take points off for that.

However, this is the only Puerto Rican food I've found in the mission, and the platanos maduros were pretty delicious. I wish I had ordered the soup instead of salad! I'll be back, but the value isn't great.
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Absolutely a wonderful dinner experience for me. The pulled pork for the Saturday special dish got me, so delicious!!! I love everything I ordered, and the pork was definitely my favorite. 

It was a Saturday after a day of work, I was feeling really happy to call it a day with a wonderful meal and great service.

Try it!!
author: Y Z.

description:
So If i was eating this back in South Florida it would only get 3  stars but since it is in San Francisco the land of the taqueria,  I'll give it 4 for being different and offering a unique cuisine to the city.

We had  vaca frita: too dry and too  shreeded lacked mojo and   the portion was small, but the black beans were on point
Mofongo:  I could not taste the pork or chicharron at all but the tomato sauce for it was amazing
Chicken soup: Was nice great broth
Tostones: Were very good and right on point  but they should of being served with a dipping sauce
Maduros were good and fried correctly

Overall  it was okay but much room for improvement.

On another note the server was very attentive and seem to know her menu well
author: Manny R.

description:
I've had Cuban and Puerto Rican food in Miami before and this rivals the best in Calle Ocho. Terrific service and amazing food.  Feel free to ask for the chef to make certain dishes to order---the restaurant is very accommodating.  I am definitely going back and taking friends to introduce them.  
Sangria was perfect, the deserts amazing and the chicken soup---OMG, what can I say---I'd go back for just the chicken soup.
Great value for your money.
author: Ray L.

description:
If you go here, get the mofongo and enjoy! The unique garlicky flavors of the fried plantains will bring joy to your taste buds.

The other items we tried - some pork chops and steak cooked in a wine sauce with peppers - were a bit on the tough, dry side. And compared to the mofongo, they paled in comparison.

Service was friendly but a bit on the slow side. We came a little after they opened up, there was only one family there beside the two of us but it took a while to get the food. 

I'd be willing to try some other items but I hope it won't be too long before I'll be getting the mofongo again.
author: Art O.

description: Extremely dissapointed, there to go menus state open today from noon-3pm, drove from the South Bay specifically to bring my peeps to the best PR food in town, just to find them closed. Not sure how they stayed in business for 40 years with false advertisement they displayed today. Unfortunety I had to rate this to post my dissapointment.
author: Marty M.

description: Came in around 4pm on a Sunday. The restaurant was out of couple of the things we wanted to order on the menu--  no biggie --- BUT Waited over an hour for our food. People who came into the restaurant after us were served before us. It looked like they gave other tables the food we had ordered. Ended up getting up and leaving because we were starving. Never offered a side dish? Some bread? Server even brought us a check for our drinks!! For real?!?! Never again!
author: Becca S.

description: Another one of my favorite dishes at this place is the Friday special, which is the paella mixta. It comes in a mini personal skillet/pan. It's got a variety of seafood -- shrimp, mussels, and clams. It also has chicken and chorizo. Delicious dish, just wished it had more seafood though!
author: Cassy H.

description:
I had purchases a Yelp! deal with this place a while ago and had to redeem it before it expired. The boyfriend and I were in the area about to go to a Brazilian Guitar concert and decided to redeem it and get some din din.

Oh my god, Reggie was an amazing server. Sometimes you just get lucky and have a waitstaff so charming that they improve your experience ten fold. This was one such experience.

The sangria is really good, really fresh. I had a happy buzz before the concert.

Loved my dish, it was some kind of pork dish that came recommended. I don't remember what my partner ordered but it was delicious as well.

Will be back!!
author: Megan D.

description:
To my great surprise we found this restaurant on the way to a cultural event. 

I was excited when I saw they had Malta, a sweet non-alcoholic refreshing beverage,  which goes good with the Puerto Rican Pasteles we had.  My wife who normally is not fond of them was pleasantly surprised. I explained to her she never had them so well prepared, and flavorful.

We also had shrimp with rice, Papa Relleno (potato balls with meat inside them),  At the time they had run out of Alcapurrias, a tasty fried dish, which didn't surprise me. I could probably clean them out by myself. They also have Coco Rico, a popular coconut soda. I guess we'll have to go back.
author: Mike D.

description:
Great environment and good service. 
The food pricing is a little high for what you get. While it is tasty I just cant go higher than 3 stars with the price considered. 
If you go with a discount you'll have a 4 star experience.
author: John N.

description:
Have been here twice and both were great experiences! I got the slow roasted pork the first time and the second time I asked for Arroz con pollo (which wasn't on the menu that day but they made it for me!). The arroz was not the usual kind I am used to eating but it was definitely delicious, the chicken was tender and very flavorful. 

All entrees come with either soup or salad, the soup is definitely a home run! 

The people who run the place are very nice and sweet. I'd definitely come back to this place.
author: Gordon O.

description: Authentic, friendly, casual and the best Mofongo I've had in 20 years! Always my birthday favorite.
author: DrRich W.

description:
I've been eating here for a few years now...I love Puerto Rican / Cuban food, and this is one of the only PR/Cuban restaurants in the city.  I haven't been here for a while, and finally went back for some dinner with friends on Friday night.  To my surprise, the restaurant is under new management now....and it's GREAT.  We ordered many different items (alcapurria, mofongo, papa rellena, pastel, maduros, roast pork, etc.) and everything was perfect.  

The previous owners were El Salvadorean...which never bothered me (you don't have to be Puerto Rican or Cuban to know how to cook the food); but I know it bothered some people, because the food didn't seem "authentic".  You'll be happy to know that the new owners are indeed Puerto Ricans.  The new owners and staff were so delightful, accommodating and friendly...I absolutely LOVE good service.

The only thing I'm worried about is that this is a really tiny place, and it seems like they will become more popular under this new management...so in the future, wait times might be kinda hectic.  With the previous owners, they were never too crowded, and I was always able to get a table anytime of the day/evening.  I suppose it wouldn't be too bad if I go super early right when they open.  Kinda sucks that the location is right in the heart of hipster-ville (I'm a Mission native, and I'm against the hipster invasions).
author: Cin W.

description:
Don't ask me how I know the owners, but I do.  For all the concerned people questioning the motherland of the owners, they are from El Salvador.  The husband and wife worked for the original owners and learned all the recipes.  Okay enough personal background.  

We went for my mother-in-laws BDay with a party of 10.5 adults (expecting mom) and 1 child.  Because it is only one person cooking we were there forever!  For appetizers we ordered the following

Yucca en ajo.  2 stars.  The yucca was boiled in a garlicky broth but failed to absorb much of the flavor.  The garlic broth was delicious however when we soaked the bread in it.

Tostones  4 stars.  On par with what tostones are supposed to be like.

Platanos fritos con crema Y frijoles fritos (fried plantains w/ refried beans and creme) 5 stars.  Although the bean to platanos ratio was not equal.

I ordered the ropa vieja.  3.5 stars.  I only have a cuban rest. in San Jose to compare it too.  I could tell the meat had been slow cooked for some time in the ingredient's and had absorbed all the flavors wonderfully.  However, the flavors were not unique and did little to distinguish themselves from Mexican flavors.  The dish was served with a side of white rice.

My husband ordered a shrimp dish in a spicy tomatoes broth. 4 stars.  
I sampled a shrimp and it tasted very fresh and well cooked.  The "spicy" broth  sauce was mild.  

Most of the adults ordered the steak sandwich, which I am kicking myself for not ordering instead.  Very big portion, juicy steak, but I did not taste it so I cant rate.

Someone else had the garlic shrimp, but had similar results as the yucca. Again I did not taste, just repeating what the other diner said.

KEY TIP!!

If you have the choice between side salad or soup, ORDER the soup.  I made the mistake of ordering the salad...it was a joke!  It was made up of chopped lettuce, canned vegetable medley (cubed carrots, green beans and peas) with a nonexistent dressing.  It was a waste of food.

The soup on the other hand, was a small bowl of chicken soup.  Very good.

Overall, I would go again to try the steak sandwich and support the owners.
author: Frida V.

description: You peeps don't know what you are missing. The food here isn't that great, especially the habichuelas rositas and mofongo. I just moved to San Francisco, so I guess I still have to find a good Puerto Rican or Dominican restaurant :(
author: David B.

description: I was there on Saturday night, 1/10/2015. Just stumbling around the area, looking for a place to eat before an event at Adobe Books. As I was reading the menu, another patron, just entering, commented that the Saturday night special was amazing. I recommend the Mango Sangria, the Camarones al Ajillo with cuban rice and the Lechon Horneado (aka Saturday special). The flavors were wonderful, and the atmosphere inviting. One of the owners was working the bar/counter and waitressing; she was a delight to talk to. Just a warm, friendly place. I'll definitely be back there!
author: John D.

description: I love this place. Never had Puerto Rican food before eating here and they have the best. The empanadas are sooo good. I love the Ropa Vieja here. Will go here time and time again.
author: Me R.

description:
yelp deal, holla!!!!

ok, ok, so I only had sangria but yum, and my friends food seemed fantastic, love the people and quaint decor.  enjoyed my time so much I got my own yelp deal and emailed another someone else as a present.  This place makes a gd present to yrself go check it out. classic cuban fare, vegetarian friendly.
author: Coco J.

description:
This place was fantastic! 
My boyfriend and I tried it out for our date night. 
The place was small but had enough tables and we did not have to wait on a Friday night at 6:30pm.
The place was super clean! All of the staff was so friendly and came over and talked with us! They made us feel like family! (I believe it is a family owned and ran place)
They gave us bottomless sangria! We ordered an appetizer and 2 entrees - the staff said it was taking a long time (we didn't notice, and I really don't think it took a long time) so they brought us an additional free appetizer and even offered us sopa but we turned that down. We also had flan for dessert.
ALL of the food was amazing! Fresh tasting and authentic!
I definitely would recommend this place and will for sure be going back!
author: Thea M.

description: Solid cuban sandwich, the maduros are glazed with this crazy Kahlua reduction that is   freaking awesome and the flan de queso reminds me of the stuff my great grandma used to make.
author: Jose d.

description: Don't waste your time with this place. Anyone who gives this place anything above 2 stars has not had authentic Puerto Rican cuisine. You want good Puerto Rican food? Make the drive and go to Sol food in Mill Valley or San Rafael. Lacked in ambiance, service was below average, and food was not happening for me. I'm Puerto Rican so I definitely know what I'm talking about.
author: Coraly S.

description: To be completely honest, I have received better and more efficient service eating at an Applebee's or Chilis. Ultimately my experience eating here was not pleasant and I do not plan to come back here ever again. Being that my family and I are Puerto Rican, I was really excited to try authentic nostalgic food. It took approximately 20 plus minutes to get waters and to be greeted at our table. We ordered pasteles, alcapurria, and rellenos de papas. Now, I am aware that pasteles takes a little more time too cook but it's not worth waiting 60 minutes even after the other dishes came out. It came down to us having to cancel the order because we were waiting at that restaurant wayyyyyy too long. The alcapurria was very hard and difficult to eat and the best item was rellenos de papas. The prices are somewhat reasonable. I didn't appreciate the woman not warning us prior that we were going to be waiting over an hour and not all of our food come out at once. The service we received along with the "ok" tasting food would make it easy for me to say dont waste your TIME or energy coming here. It makes me sad that I am not recommending a place that serves my cultures food but there are other restaurants in San Francisco that you will have a much better experience and the food wouldn't be less than amazing. As patient as we were you would think they would of just given us the pasteles even if we cancelled the order out of the inconvenience of us not receiving the main entree ordered. Its safe to say they don't take pride in the service provided. If you have 2 or more hours to waste and you don't mind mediocre tasting good then you might be pleased.
author: Melissa R.

description: im from nyc and there's a big puerto rican population there and restaurants that cook great authentic pr food. im no expert on the cuisine, but this place was just...meh. ordered a chicken dish, a pork dish, the tamale-type appetizer and some smoothies. basically everything was pretty bland. but prices were ok i guess. every dish was under 15 bucks. but overpriced compared to the street vendors who hawk real pr food on the streets of ny!!
author: p f.

description: Mediocre food, reheated rice, bland tilapia, over sugared fruit shake... Do not recommend.
author: Manal D.

description: Food is good. I likes the ap with plantain, yucca, beef and raisins. Sangria was delicious. Staff is super nice, they even refilled our sangria which came free with my groupon!
author: Amy C.

description: This place is a joke! Walked in at around 745pm, the place was not entirely full. We sat down, the waitress gave us our menus over a table that had not been wiped down. Upon taking our order, the waitress informed us that there were three dishes that were not available. Upsetting, but we ordered other stuff. We waited about 25 mins and no appetizers came. I was starting to think that I should've listened to the Yelp reviews regarding the service. A party of two walked in maybe 20 minutes after we did and they got their dishes within 15 minutes! Unbelievable! I questioned the waitress and she said that our food was coming. Shortly after she gives us tostones that we ordered and says that they don't have any bread left for the cubano sandwich! Why did they have to wait this long to let us know they had no bread? We asked her to cancel our entire order since nothing had been cooked yet. Don't waste your time coming here...the service is not worth it...
author: H C.

description: Food was awesome. Service was great. Very cute restaurant right near a book store and ice cream... no complaints!
author: Ginna B.

description: Came here with friends through a groupon reserve program (25% off the bill) to have some puerto rican food. The place looks like an honest local business, not too big, not too fancy, just very pleasant, like you're at a friend's place. Waiters were nice, helped with recommendations and didn't bother us unnecesarily. Mofongo starter was excellent as well as all meat entrees we ordered (pork and beef). I can see myself coming here often.
author: Marina R.

description: 1 word Authentic! I grew up in Miami and everything about this place is true to it's roots. Usually, West Coast Cuban food, it has a fusion aspect to it. That is not what I was looking for and that's not what you'll find here. My recommendation would be the Bistec Empanizado. Num!
author: Adam K.

description:
deliciosa
(3.25 stars)

Living social deal went into good use.

- Food, good
- Prices, decent
- Service, good
- Ambiance, small and cute

I recall them being a vendor at SF Street Food Festival but did not get a chance to try them out. Craving "cuban food" and came this way to get my fixings. I've had cuban food before and always enjoyed it because the dishes are very flavorful. I wanted to give this place more stars, i really do, but something in the food kind of lacks.

HEFFER STATUS.

ROPA VIEJA ($14.25) - Shredded flank steak cooked in creole sauce, onions, tomatoes, wine, and bell peppers. includes rice, black beans, and soup or salad. I chose soup because i see other yelps ranting about how good the chicken soup was. OMG THE CHICKEN SOUP (even if it was a small side cup of it) WAS THE BEST!!!!  When the dish came out the portion was decent, not sure if thats their average size or they docked off some because I was purchasing on a Living Social deal.Very good and flavorful. I think I'll just order the chicken soup by itself next time LOL. I didn't really see raisins in my meal, which was fine i prefer to eat raisins by themselves then mixed with a main course. The meat was tender and shredded easily, the flavors of the sauce mixed well with the meat/rice/beans however kind of lacked the strong flavor that I'm use to when eating cuban food, also came with a side of crunch plantains which i wasn't too fond of. I prefer the nice cooked plantains, not these plantain chips with no flavor. 

Will I be back? Yes. it may not have been the best cuban food but its still delicious.

Until the next review....
author: Jane A.

description:
Its a Cuban Restaurant that has some Puerto Rican specialties. 
I had the:
* Puerto Rican Pasteles
* White Rice
* Pink Beans 
* Fried Green Plantains (tostones)

Its a small cozy restaurant with some low volume music that sets the atmosphere. 

The food was well prepared and oh soooooo good. 

The plantains were fried just right. 

The Rice was what I'm used to finding in Dominican and Puerto Rican kitchens.

The Pink Beans (Habichuelas Rosada) were very very well seasoned.

The Puerto Rican Pastel was amazingly good and they sell them frozen as well.  

The combination of cozyness, excellent food and amicable staff made this well worth the trip and I greatly look forward to going back again.
author: Seth R.

description: Let me start off by saying that you cannot compare this place to anything you've ever eaten in New York or Miami. With that said, overall the food was delicious. It lacked a bit in the true Latin flavor but I am assuming that it may be harder to get some of the ingredients on the west coast because I cannot find them. We ordered several items off of the menu. Plantanos Maduros and Alcapurrias. Unfortunately, they did not have any pastels. The plantains were nice and sweet and the  Picadillio was well seasoned. We each ordered a main dish. The Lechon and the Bistec. Everything tasted great, it just lacked flavor. Both meats were tender. The reason I give this place 4 stars is because their service was superb and their drink specials (pitcher of Sangria) was just what we needed to quench our Sunday thirst. I would say, give it a try, it's probably the closest in Puerto Rican/Cuban food you will come in contact with in the Bay Area.
author: Claudine P.

description: Love, Love, Love this place! Best Boriqua cuisine in SF!!!! Their Mofongo is AMAZING!...along with the garlic shrimp salad, bistec, white sangria and red sangria. Everything I've ordered here has been delicious!!!! I am now a REGULAR at "El Nuevo Frutilandia!" =)
author: Claire K.

description: We booked a reservation for 8pm for 4 people. We showed up 30 minutes early because we saw half the tables available. We asked to be seated early. The waitress acted strange, checked with the cooks, came back and told us they ran out of food. She said they got too busy and they're now closed. Only half the tables where occupied and it was 7:30pm on a Saturday night. No courtesy phone call. No explanation. Amateur hour.
author: darren l.

description: Thank For groupon! Oh man I will not be back. My beans were so salty! I could barely eat them.
author: Gabriela H.

description: By far the best Cuban Restaurant in SF and the best thing is no Cubans Chef  around the kitchen. Very friendly owners who I had known for more than 12 years, as a Cuban when I hit the city I stop by with friends & family. I actually recommend this restaurant when Rueda de Casino Congress is happening in SF the second week of February.
author: Leo L.

description: I got an Amazon deal, took my mother out for her birthday and I fell in love with this place. the waitress wonderful, the food even better very exotic something totally new for usn We had the tostoned with galic what a wonderful treat. The food was great. I have to take my husband.
author: Carolyne R.

description:
This place was delicious. Given the affordable menu and delicious sangria, we will be back. Servers were pretty excited but the food was delicious and experience was awesome. 

We had the Chile relleno and the pulled pork. Pink beans are ridiculously good. White sangria was addictive too. Rafael, the owner, was super nice and checked in with us often. 

All around, pleasant experience. A few characters on staff but made for a fun dinner out. We will be back often.
author: Geoff R.

description: Flavors of the food are not the correct ones for puertorrican plates...the mofongo was the only good thing that we ordered, even the sangría didn't taste right. Way over-priced!!! Not coming back!
author: Liliana B.

description: Finally a Cuban/Puerto Rican restaurant in SF! This east coast/southern gal has missed this type of authentic cuisine. I ordered the sangria and the Vegetarian Mofongo and was not disappointed. Can't wait to drop by again!
author: Whitney W.

description: Went here last night. I've been meaning to try this place for years and was really excited. When we sat down, the server informed us that several menu items were unavailable. Okay, totally normal. We ordered two entrees from the available menu items and then later were told by the server both dishes were also unavailable. Since we already had our drinks, we decided to stay. We improvised and ordered vegetarian empanadas and salad and asked for any dish at all that they could make with fish or with chicken, whether or not it was on the menu. (I don't eat pork and my friend doesn't eat shell fish). When the server came back, she informed us there was no chicken or fish improv options AND that the vegetarian empanadas were also unavailable. The cook did improvise a Maduro empanada for us, which was delicious. The server was extremely kind and apologetic and they gave us a significant discount on the sangria and appetizers we ate. Still, by the time we finished our drinks, it was too late to get food anywhere else and I went home hungry. I would give this place another try to see if this was a fluke. The menu *looked* exciting and the server was really nice, but otherwise this was a total bummer for us, and probably for them too because they lost significant sales and it must have been really hard for the server too!
author: Gabby G.

description:
A little disappointed actually.  After hearing some hype on the joint and remembering I got a quite delicious Cubano sandwich from them at the San Francisco Street Festival, I was excited to try the place especially after being turned away a week ago because its was packed, close to closing time, and claimed "they were out of food".
Tonight there it was only about 20% full, perhaps because its a holiday weekend.
The standard most be low on 24th Street because I ordered the  Bistec De Palomilla (Tender thin top sirloin steak sauteed with orange-lemon sauce garnished with onions and parsley. includes rice, black beans, and soup )and I can't even say it looked good.  It was Not tender and a bit flavorless.  Like a rubbery chip steak.
My partner had the Ropa Vieja (Shredded flank steak cooked in creole sauce, onions, tomatoes, wine, and bell peppers. includes rice, black beans, and soup).  It wasn't even actually what he ordered but it was comparable as far as the menu was concerned so he just went along with it.  I tasted it and though I liked it better then my order, it was certainly nothing to write home about.  Presentation was that of a school cafeteria and there wasn't even a plantano on the plate.  Portions were small.
I may go by there again for the Cuban Sandwich during lunch hours someday if I'm in the hood but don't hold your breath.  
We will stick to our favorite in the Haight for this style food from now on.  It has price points, atmosphere, and presentation.  None of which I could vouch for this place.  Go to Parada 22 instead.
author: John W.

description: Thanks to a groupon deal I revisited after many years. I tried their Wednesday special of chicken and rice. I was very happy and most importantly my 20 month old devoured his food. We'll be back!
author: L P.

description:
Ouch, this really hurts. I so wanted to love this place. Disappointed is a strong word. Perhaps too strong for the food in this case. Underwhelmed might be more appropriate. However, disappointed is probably not a strong enough descriptor of the service. 

I arrived about 30 minutes before my wife and ordered a beer while I waited. Knowing that she would be starving when she got there, I also ordered one alcapurria and some maduros. When my wife arrived, I had finished my beer and the waittress came over. We ordered another beer, a water for my wife, and she commented that the apps would be right out. 10 minutes later when she finally came to get our food order, none of those three things had come out yet. She said they would be right out. 10 minutes later, my beer came. My wife asked again for her water. 10 minutes later, still no water and no apps. We asked again and finally got the water. Eventually the apps came as well, but by that time it had been almost an hour since I ordered them and they were really no longer necessary. No apology or even acknowledgement of the wait. I cook maduros all the time at home. They take 5 minutes; cut and fry, it's really that simple. 

Unfortunately, the maduros were not very good either. They were really dry and not greasy or juicy at all like they are usually served, negative stars for the wait and disappointing presentation. The alcapurria was alright, but lacked a bit of flavor, 3 stars. I also ordered a pastel, which I had gotten to go before, so I knew not to expect much, meh, 2.5 stars. I got the mofongo, which was alright, but nothing compared to the version at Parada 22, another 2.5 stars. The wifey got the special of the day, fricase de pollo. This dish was alright, 3 stars is fair. I make a better version, in both of our opinions, but it had decent flavor. 

The services just really killed it. It literally took an hour to get the apps. The waittress must have been newish. She seemed very uncomfortable with the names of the dishes on the menu, not to mention the Spanish pronunciations, always referring to them by their English descriptions (e.g., "oh, so you want the sweet plantains?"). She seemed confused a lot and, for some reason, was struggling despite there being three servers and only 5 small tables. 

We will not be back for dinner. I could return for pasteles to go, but only if I get really desperate.
author: Miguel V.

description: Hadn't been here in ages and sadly, won't be coming up. Shocked at how expensive the bill was for the portions we received. Not proportional and we left hungry after a casual $50+ bill. If you're hungry for Puerto Rican food, worth taking the bus/car to Sol Food in Marin. Healthy, filling portions for a fraction of the price.
author: Mayra P.

description:
Okay so I 'm Puerto Rican from NYC and I was excited to come and try the food here. Since we are a minority on this side and there are'nt many places to try Puerto Rican food I thought I was excited to try this place . Well firstly the people who cook here are not PR's....the food is okay nothing that is going to make me crave for this place at all. - food lacks flavor...service was okay

the mofongo lacked the pork fat that is usually added to it. and the pernil lacked so much flavor.
author: michelle r.

description: I live in the neighborhood and have been meaning to try this place for awhile.  Honestly, don't bother.  Considering the place was nearly empty the service was terrible.  Was excited to try the mofongo, but it was not impressive.  All the other dishes (when the food finally did come) were incredibly bland and tasteless.
author: Sam G.

description: Dinner here is one of the best values you can find, and this is among few restaurants in the Mission where vegetarians and non-vegetarians can all enjoy excellent, authentic food from other parts of the Americas. The flavors are wonderful, and the execution has been flawless on every dish I've ordered here, including, most recently, the red snapper. The place is small, unassuming, and usually not very busy... just how we like it, but in this case, definitely deserving of more traffic!
author: David S.

description:
1 star seemed too harsh, so I'm going with 2. But the fact that I considered going with 1 star should tell you something.

I'm 1st generation Cuban American, originally from Miami, FL, so I know my way around the Cuban Food block. Now I can't say how they do PR food or sandwiches, but I can tell you they don't do Bistec de Palomilla well at all. And that's enough for me to know not to comeback. Why? Bistec de Palomilla is the quintessential Cuban dish. White rice, black beans, and steak. Done. A Cuban joint messing that dish up is like an Italian restaurant doing lousy spaghetti and meatballs. 

The palomilla at Frutilandia was greasy, the seasoning was all wrong, and it was pounded way too thin. If that wasn't bad enough, the white rice had some rock-hard, bottom of the dish grains in it. As for the black beans, they were passable. 

The entree came with a salad which consisted of lettuce 2 slices of tomato and Veg-all corn, carrots and green beans. It was kind of a travesty, actually. The best part of the meal was the warm bread and the nice server. Everything else was bad and low budget.

Good service and atmosphere go a long way with me and I don't know about their PR food or sandwiches, so I'll give them the benefit of the doubt and give them 2 instead of 1 star.
author: Gil M.

description: Love this place- the food is amazing- plantains delicious, momfungo amazing- shrimp with garlic sauce delicious the only lacking thing is the service- but it's a small run operation so will be back!
author: Jill S.

description: I am probably the most picky eater to ever hit this earth... So to get five stars from me is most definitely an accomplishment. I walked in today after work and really wasn't looking for a full meal. However, I seen on the menu their camarones and I had to try it. It was shrimp in a creole hot sauce and I must say it was Epic! The best dish I have ever ordered anywhere hands down.  The flavors where perfection! I ordered the creole sauce hot (you have the option of hot or not) the heat was just enough! Not over whelming and perfect taste. I was very impressed by the service as well. Would definitely go back and recommend to EVERYONE!
author: Ms'Ducky S.

description:
Excellent service, personable, friendly folks. Excellent food and descriptions.  ( I do not know Cuban and Puerto Rican food-they have both)
Owned by a husband and wife team, they both wait tables.
author: Carol K.

description: This is our second time to this place and it is now under new administration.  The flavors of the food are amazing.  Very traditional and true to the Puerto Rico and Cuban roots.  The tres leche is amazing and we are very picky about it.  Definitely will come back and suggest you come here and enjoy some good Caribbean food.  Thank you very much for serving the best and having the best customer service around.
author: Roxana R.

description:
I really like this place.  Yea, its not like the Cuban restaurants in Florida, but the food is good and the people are really nice.  Its run by an older couple that like to speak Spanish, which is nice cause I need to practice.  Its reasonably priced, they give you free bread while you wait, which is great cause the food is not prepared quickly.  
Go, if you want a place where you can enjoy a good meal, in a quiet cosy environment where you can actually have a conversation with friends.  Its just a nice, low-key spot with good food, good service, and no crowds.
author: Peter S.

description: I'm a fan of Puerto Rican/ Cuban food and have eaten quite a bit of it. This was just ok. We ordered quite a bit as we wwere starving: Pastel Puertorriquenos, Platanos Maduros, Alcapurria, Tostones con Mojo de Ajo, Cubano sandwich, Passion fruit shake, and sweet potato fries. Everything tasted fine.. just not out of this world. On the other hand, service was really good. The place is cute, I like the location at the Mission. Not a bad place at all.
author: Vol T.

description: Friendly, attentive service combined with delicious, authentic Cuban food. The tostonas with lemon and garlic; the spinach empanadas; the Cuban sandwiches; and flan were soooo good. I would go back any time. It was like being in Miami.
author: Harvey H.

description: Soooo excited!!! No more driving to San Rafael for awesome Puerto Rican/Cuban food. The pork chops are so good and delicious, tostones are done just right. Had the sample plate and it was yummy!!!!! I would defintly come back again and again. Staff was awesome!
author: Paulie R.

description:
Wow! 

I love CUBAN FOOD! Especially, the hole in the wall places.  

My boyfriend ordered the cuban sandwich and I ordered the thin sirloin steak marinated in lemon and herb sauce with sauted onions, rice and black beans.  My dish came with a bowl of chicken soup.  

Everything on our table was the best Cuban food that I have had in a very long time! I would definitely come back again and again!
author: Honey T.

description: Great vegetarian mofongo, but disappointed they don't serve fried pork. The service was a little slow, but everything was delicious. We'll be back.
author: Kitzzy A.

description: My husband and I just came from having lunch at El Nuevo Fruitlandia.  We visited this restaurant quite a few times when the previous owner ran it and we always enjoyed their traditional Cuban and Puerto Rican dishes.  The new owners have added a few new dishes and have kept the traditional dishes but elevated them to new heights.  I had their paella, which included mussels, clams, chicken, sausage and shrimp.  The rice in this dish had wonderful texture and deep rich flavors and was cooked to perfection and kept hot in the pan it was served in, which added to the presentation.  My husband had the slow-roasted pork marinated in garlic, pineapple, and Caribbean spices.  He loved the everything about his dish and topped it off with a dark beer.  We split a side order of platoons and fought over the last piece. The service was friendly and professional.  The prize is in the preparation of their tasty dishes.
author: rita m.

description:
I'm a huge fan of Cuban food, and being in the Mission, decided to try this place out for lunch. The space was clean and organized. Service was very attentive, and the owner helped me figure out what I wanted. He even brought me a few things to try. I love when that happens!

Food-- 3.5 stars. It needs a little help. The salad dressing wasn't very good, and all of the appetizers and the entree was just "Okay". Nothing amazing.

Ambience--4 stars. I loved the cuban music, and the space was clean and bright.

Service--4.5 stars. Very attentive

Price--4 stars. Very reasonable.
author: Amanda D.

description:
Must haves:
  Chicken soup
  Platano maduro
  Tostones

The rest of food was very delicious- but the above were excellent.  I lived in Puerto Rico for 2 years and never enjoyed mofongo, but the food here has a definate Island flavor.  

Sit by the window and enjoy the food traffic on 24th street, especially nice on a sunny day!
author: Brenda B.

description: Delicious Cuban and Puerto Rican food!  I was searching for a PR restaurant serving alcapurria, finally found it here and it was delicious!!!!!  Mofongo, was excellent and moist!  (most places I've had it make it too dry, not here!!). Chuletas were moist and perfectly seasoned!!  The sangria was yummy too!  Can't wait to go back!!
author: Diane F.

description:
Growing up with my grandmother's authentic Puerto Rican cuisine, it was defnitely  a sad day when I moved to the Bay and realized there was not a plethora of PR food (or PR people for that matter) out here.

So excited to try this place andbrought two of my new friends in Cali with me.  Service was good, overpriced for a glass of wine.

We Had:
Pastel- the best part of the meal, definitely not the best that I have had but edible
Pork- Bit dry and not well seasoned
Rice with piegeon peas- no flavor, nothing like rice I am used to
Tostones- ok but dry
Yuca- decent
Alcapurria- so burnt could not even bite into!
Papa Rellenos- did not come with gravy, not taste or flavor and the potato was crumbly

Overall, not a good meal but the service was good.  Would not recommend but I guess if you have never had authentic PR food better than nothing.

On another note, if interested, there is a PR festival this Saturday 7/18 in San Jose go to www.wrprc.org.  The $ goes towards scholarships for higher education and I am hoping the food will be better
author: Jeannie S.

description: I just moved out here like a year ago from ct im puerto rican and i love my puerto rican food i harley eat it that much cause my mom and family live back in ct. I found out about this place and i was so excited so i decided to visit and man it was good food is great the service is awesome! the place is small but doesnt matter to me. I got a bowl of soup when i tasted it , it reminded me of my moms cooking great place great spanish food.
author: Steven S.

description:
My wife and I love this place. The food is not as greesy as it once was and as puerto rican can sometimes be. But the authentic "must try" in this place are the pastellas. Go ahead and try to find them anywhere else on the west coast. We had a devil of a time finding this unique dish.

Mmm mmmmm....
author: Thomas B.

description: I'm not usually excited about a spot after eating there, but I can't stop talking about how good this place is. Maybe it's all the sangria that they kept pouring, but regardless this place is legit. The service was great. Really nice group of people. The pork with Caribbean spices was so good I wish I knew how to make it at home. My boyfriend and I are sure to become regulars after this. A Groupon well spent.
author: Rachel A.

description: This is the best and only Cuban restaurant in San Francisco.  On main and main in the Mish, this little restaurant is clean and homey.  It's your Mom's home cooking if she was Cuban.  The chicken soup that comes with the entree is generous and delicious.  Be sure to try their wide selection of fruit shakes.  A good change from your typical taqueria on 24th Street.
author: Laurence H.

description: My boyfriend and I ate here last night and everything was delicious. We had the pulled pork and red snapper for our entrees as well as some sweet plantains which are listed as an appetizer (but I think they taste better with the entrees).
