The sangria was really good and the service was super friendly and happy to answer all of my questions about unfamiliar ingredients. The place is casual but very clean and warm feeling which made it comfortable for a sit down dinner experience. I would definitely go back and recommend this place.
author: Natasha K.

description:
I would give it 3 stars if there were more Cuban or PR restaurants in the city to which I could compare this one to, but there aren't.  So 4 stars it is.  Because honestly, I enjoy dining here.

They have this great chicken dish thats covered in some sort of green sauce.  A little on the salty side, but pretty tasty otherwise.  Standard rice and beans.

Do NOT, and i repeat, DO NOT, respond with "salad" when asked for "salad or soup"... it is the most bare salad i've ever been served, and they don't even offer dressing.  At most, some olive oil and pepper.  The soup, on the otherhand, is delicious and absolutely bread-dip worthy.


The city needs more Cuban restaurants... i long for Bistec de Palomilla done the right way.
author: Gina L.

description:
I'm not Puerto Rican, but does it really matter? 

Good food is good food & Fruitlandia hasn't disappointed in the two times I've been in a 4-day period. 

Order this and you'll be happy: 
Molfondo w/Gravy: Totally F-yeah worthy & the server loves to say how good it is (and you'll love when she does). 
Tostones con Mojo de ajo: Your date will thank you 
Sopa de Pollo: Better than anything your mother makes (seriously, pass on the dinner salad and get the damn soup)

By the way, whoever said the wine is expensive is a total dummy. $3 is like less than 2 bus rides.
author: Jonathan C.

description: Food was above average (mine was good, my friend didn't like theirs as much) but the atmosphere and service were outstanding.
author: Phillip W.

description: I'm a Puerto Rican from Puerto Rico, not 2nd generation or from the east coast so I know as a fact how the food from island taste.  I have to say that when I tasted the mofongo I felt like I was back at home.  Awesome mofongo, the tostones were great, the papa rellena was great, maduros (we call it amarillos) were great, pasteles were great.  Overall the food was awesome, not 5 star because the rice and beans was just ok, not great, and the malta was not malta india from Puerto Rico, was some other brand that we dont have in the island. Hightly recommended!!!  Tell Carmen that John sent you.
author: John Q.

description: I finally found a place for my days when Im homesick and Im craving some of my mom's food. Delicious Caribbean flavors! I was craving Cuban food on a sunday night and found this place here on Yelp. I saw the menu and immediately jumped on Bart and walked the streets of the Mission to find this small and cozy Cuban/PR joint. Since the minute I walked it I was like, ok, this looks good! the music and the art in the walls was authentic from the island. I ordered the Papa Rellena which is Cuabn and it was very flavorful. My favorite was the Mofongo, I would eat this all day every day when Im at home. and this one was very delicious as well and the presentation was super cute. Portions were big, big, big! The chef is Puerto Rican so he knows about which flavors to incorporate one each dish. IS definitely a most go if you are craving a delicious meal from the island. Prices are good as well. I will probably come to Frutilandia every weekend now that i have discovered it.
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
When you are homesick, this place works. When you can't drive to San Rafael to Sol Food, this place works. When you just want comfort food and feel at home, this place works.
When you are with friends celebrating a b-day and explaining the dishes and tell stories from your childhood eating this food, this place works. Don't expect glorious dishes, just nice comfort food.
author: Cristina R.

description:
Note- that this place has been taken over by new owners since my original post. Still good food. But missing the "grandma" touch.

***
This place was an absolute find for my wife and I. Having lived in Miami for a while, we were both craving a spot that would give us our fix of Cuban food. Paladar never cut it for me.

This seems to be a joint that is run by an older husband and wife team. The chicken soup that comes with the dishes is great. None of that canned chicken stock - you can tell that the chef makes her own.  We always ask the cook to make us some arroz con gris along with our food and she is always nice enough to oblige. My main staple in the place is the Ropa Veija - which i think is as good as I've had elsewhere.

I read in some other whiney post that the owner is Dominican - but who cares. The food is among the best cuban food you can get in the bay area.
author: Vijay S.

description:
There are only 10 and a half Puerto Ricans in the Bay Area, I am one of them and "nine" of them are related to me. Not even the owners of Fruliandia are Puerto Rican. The only Puerto Rican restaurant in S.F. and they're not Puerto Rican. That gives me an idea.

OK, maybe there are more boricua but I don't know them and it hasn't stopped this place from making great food. I usually get the same thing everytime. Mofongo and alcapurrias and tostones. My family also orders pasteles from them every year at Christmas time to bring home. Pasteles are a type of plantain dumpling that can have pork and other things and are usually wrapped in banana leaves (like my grandmother used to do) or cooking parchment.

Everything I've had there has tasted authentic and I like to bring out of town guests there to let them sample the food of my people. It's a small place in the Mission and there only ever seems to be two people working so it's not good for large groups.

There are a couple of other places I found on the other side of the bridge but that is a separate review. For now, Frutilandia is the best place to go for Puerto Rican food. Oh yeah, and I guess Cuban food too.
author: Hunter G.

description: What a trainwreck! Was so excited to find Puerto Rican food so close to me. Went for dinner on a Sunday, never again. The place had just opened for the evening, we sat down and began to drool over the selection. We placed our order only to be denied at almost every request. After finally completing out order, of what we could order, we waited.........and waited. A party of six walked in about 20 mins after we were seated. As soon as they were seated, They had appetizers served. I glanced over to the table, those are the same appetizers we had order over 20min ago.  Then a party of two were seated, they received appetizers as well. By this point I'm trying to scowl my eye contact with staff with no effect. "That's it" I belched! I walked to the counter to tell them we were leaving. "Here is your bill for the soda" he sang out with a look of glee on his face. He had the nerve to tell me my food was on its way out as we were leaving. I just wanted to let yelp know, we went to "Red Balloon" around the corner and was served in less that 15min.
author: Juan Carlos R.

description:
This is probably THE only SF restaurant that specializes in Puerto Rican food from what I can tell, but don't hold me to that.  I went here with a friend on Friday night before a jazz concert at the Red Poppy Art House, and the restaurant is tiny but in a cozy way as opposed to a clausterphobic way.  The night I went there was only one lady manning the bar, taking orders, and serving food but she was really sweet and patient since I didn't know what I wanted to order and we didn't have to wait too long for anything.

Excellent dishes enjoyed that night include  Mofongo (mashed plantains and pork sauteed with garlic and olive oil...that you dip in a secret sauce), Pierna de Puerco Horneado (really tender pork with carribean spices) served with a tasty side of dish of rice and beans and my friend had the Ropa Vieja (flank steak in a creole sauce) even though I meant to tell him that I heard the Vaca Frita (fried shredded flank steak) was the way to go.  He enjoyed his dish regardless.

At $9.95 for an entre, I thought the prices here were cheap.    I'm glad I found this place (via Yelp btw) ...I'll definitely bring some friends here in the future....especially since the Red Poppy is right around the corner.
author: LaSha G.

description:
Before anything else this place is 3.3 to 3.5 stars...

The sandwiches are really tasty. I didn't order a sandwich but ended up getting one anyways, I guess the waitress misheard me. It was really good so how can I complain? Maybe she secretly knew I wanted a sandwich and changed it for me :)? They give you cup of sauce with your mofongo that's really tasty, I recommend using it in conjunction with the sandwich for maximum taste utility. 

The service isn't super quick so have the expectation when you go in and it will help.

I'm usually a tortas man but this sandwich is in the top 3 of latin sandwiches.
author: Michael S.

description:
Aye, caramba!  My Cuban and Puerto Rican relatives are rolling over in their graves. Sorry folks, this place is such a disappointment.

I'm jaded.  My Grandmother taught my Mom how to cook Cuban food.  My Mom taught me.  I'd rather take the time and cook my own than eat here.  Except for Ropa Vieja because that is one big pain in the culito to make.

I'm still searching for a decent Cuban place in the City other than mi casa.  If anyone finds one, please let me know.
author: Liz P.

description: The service was pretty bad but it was a busy Friday night so not overly surprised. The food was good, the surtido which has tostones, maduros (ripe plantains) and yucca were all really good. Mofongo was a bit dry and there was only maybe three shrimp in there made it a little less dry with the sauce on it. Black beans were decent, could have used a little more flavor but it was better than the last time I went which was almost 5 years ago (judging from the review I am looking at). Also, on the menu it should say that the pink beans have pork in it because friend of mine almost ate it and she is vegetarian. She discovered this after a bite and could taste the pork. At least the server should have informed us but they were fairly busy when we got there so I guess some important details were missed. Life goes on. I would go back but not during the weekend or at least during a time that they're not so busy. I am Puerto Rican so I know what this food should taste like, so I think there's definitely room for improvement. The empanadas de espinacas were quite good and one of my meat eating friends liked the alcapurrias.
author: Gina R.

description: Fast service. I got the food within 10 minutes after ordering. Food was delicious. Got the black beans and slow roasted pork. Black beans were awesome as they have bacon in them! Perfect portion size filling. The Chef/owner is really nice and friendly too.
author: Shari B.

description:
This place made me do the Happy Dance!  
The Ropa Vieja (shredded beef) dish was every bit as fantastically fabulous as the other reviewers promised.  Lots of peppers and onions mixed in, and not a hint of fattiness.  Just perfectly cooked, flavorful shredded beef served simply with rice and beans.  Awesome, 
Will definitely be adding this cozy little restaurant to my local rotation.
author: Becca V.

description:
I had wanted to try this restaurant for some time but was always hesitant due to the inconsistent reviews it's received on here.  My Puerto Rican partner's craving for home cooking and his desire to give this caucasian American a taste of the Island finally won out and I decided to give it a try with an open mind, and I sure am glad I did!  

We arrived Sat. around 1:00 PM and only two of the 12 tables were occupied, with one waitress on duty.  After an hour about half of the tables were filled, all with what appeared to be local Mission folks, including a charming elderly couple, which I took as a good sign of authentic food.  On this day, service seemed casual as opposed to slow (as other reviewers have reported), but I could see it perhaps slowing down if it was too full or if too many people arrived at once.

Food-wise, everything we ordered was delicious, including the each-piece-separately-toasted French table bread.  I ordered the Pastel app. on Yelp's recommendation, which I enjoyed quite a bit but wished was more tamale-like for my personal taste.  The Al Capurria was like a yummy meat-filled yucca donut which I'd definitely order again.  The complimentary chicken soup was as good as I'd want a chicken soup to be, properly salted and with very soft, moist chunks o'chicken.

For entrees we had Ropa Vieja (which my parter swore was properly cooked and had an authentic flavor), and Camarones al Ajillo, seven perfectly cooked shrimp in an amazing lemon-butter sauce.  We also tried the Chiles Rellenos just for the sake of comparison, and although they were much wetter than I expected or have had before (served in a casserole dish filled with sauce), they tasted great.  The breading was of course not crispy due to all the sauce, but it was still discernible and added to the flavor and texture of the peppers.  

Regarding the side of beans which others have reviewed as "watery and bland," my partner says the thinner sauce is the authentic Puerto Rican style.  I don't personally like watery beans, but I found this sauce to be just thick enough on its own and was especially good with the addition of rice, which I mixed in to all the sauces we were served. I felt the beans were "delicately spiced" rather than bland, meant to be a basic accompaniment, not a main flavor feature.

Some reviews on here have negatively critiqued the decor, though I found it to be basic but charming, likening it to a restaurant you'd find along the road while traveling in the Island countryside.  It at least appeared to be very clean.  I didn't give the restrooms a try.

I don't know if time of day or day of week are factors in some of the inconsistencies people have reported, but I'd recommend making your own decision.  Just be open-minded in regards to some of the negative comments and you should be OK.
author: Tim D.

description: Great food! We ordered tapas (empanadas, mofongo, sweet plantains), as well as the slow roasted pork. We topped it off with sangria. Everything was delicious!
author: Nia A.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed El Nuevo Fruitlandia yet. This place is probably the first hidden treasure I found when moving to the Mission a few years ago. My father lived in Puerto Rico and has always grumbled about the lack of Puerto Rican food in the bay area. So when he requested Carne Guisada (a slow cooked pork stew) for his birthday dinner, I thought, "hey, I'm in the Mission, I can figure this out." We were not dissapointed. El Nuevo Fruitlandia is now a family staple.

Theres a whole list of fried goodness for appetizers: the tostones (smooshed and fried slices of platano) are my favorite, although I wish they had some homemade salsa and not just tapatio. They bring you warm toasted water bread while you're waiting, too, which my sister adores. 

You can tell they've made an effort to cater to vegetarians, which I really appreciate. The chile rellenos (about $7) are the best I've had, in a rich tomato and chile sauce with bell pepers and onions. The mofongo (smashed fried yucca)we get the vegetarian) is also very good, if a bit greasy. The platanos maduros (sweet) are reminiscent of fried bananas but somehow savory and delicious with lots of hot sauce and the white rice and black beans that come with every entree. Yucca con mojo is always perfectly cooked, creamy and so tasty with the lemon they give you squeezed on top. We usually order the salad, too, which is simple but fresh and good, with cucumbers, corn, onions and romaine.

They also have lots of juices and shakes. I like the juices, but last time I got the shake and it tasted like frothy milk and sugar -- I could barely taste the fruit at all, which was weird. 

The service is very slow but that's because they make everything fresh right when you order it.

This is one of those unique little gems that reminds me how damn lucky I am to live in San Francisco.
author: Suzanne S.

description: It's a cozy little place and has a great selection of traditional Cuban/Puerto Rican cuisine, including a number of veggie options.  Vegetarian mofongo!  Yucca!  Plantains!  Food is made to order, so expect a bit of a wait.
author: Andi T.

description:
We just finished another great dinner at El Nuevo Frutilandia.  I'm even more impressed because we got to chat a bit with the waitress.  Just learned this restaurant has been open for over 25 years, that the friendly cute waitress Irene (EE reh neh) has been working there for the past 9 and they are not Puerto Ricans or Cubans...  This is why we were both even more impressed.  The food is well done!

I've been craving PR cooking for a while, so I got a fix tonight.  I went with my friend Rita C who is from the Dominican Republic; you can say we know Caribbean food!

We ordered mostly tapas stile entrees and we started with the famous MOFONGO, excellent!

Followed by ALCAPURRIAS- not bad but I miss the regular just plantain alcapurrias, these are made with yucca also.

We also had a YUCCA AL MOJO dish and followed by a BACALAO GISAU WITH RICE (stew of cod fish with steam rice) which came with the chicken soup or green salad.  The yucca was perfect and the bacalao less salty than I'm used to, but flavorful.  

I most say, their chicken soup is darn good.  The most authentic Puerto Rican chicken soup I've had outside of the island.

This was a Thursday evening and they were not crowded.  However, the mofongo usually takes a while to prepare, so order it as soon as you are seated.  While you wait, enjoy some warm bread!

===================================================

The only Puerto Rican restaurant I've been able to find in the city.  And trust me, I've looked!
Not disappointing, try the mofongo, I love their version.  Maybe not before a hot date/night...  Two words - garlic breath.
Small, cozy, friendly waitress and good inexpensive menu selection - I'm coming back!
author: Yamil A.

description:
Ok so gotta give them 3 stars because they went out of their way to accommodate us but I was expecting better...

Sunday evening, after a trip to MoMA we made a much anticipated trip to Frutilandia.  Keep in mind, I'm Puerto Rican -born and raised- so I know what most of the dishes should taste like.  Trying to be reasonable I don't expect them to be up on "tastes like when grandma makes them" status but at least I expect them to taste like if I went to a hole in the wall place in NYC.

We drive by slowly to check the location around 6:45pm when I see the sign that says CLOSED... Hmm, their website says the hours are until 8pm...  Circled the block and decided to get out of the car and look to see if it was a 4th of July weekend thing but nope, no hours on the door either, hmm.  Then I see her, the waitress inside.  I proceed to knock and signal her to come on over... Success, she heeds my call.  Busted out the Spanish to seem more convincing and she explains that even though they are cleaning they could serve us if we didn't mind.  Score, we go in.

I had looked at the menu online and had pretty much an idea of what I wanted.  There were a couple of things they didn't have (won't hold it against them since they were closing after all) which were the guava juice and the chicken soup that you can have instead of the green salad.  Order for two looked something like this:

- 1 alcapurria
- 1 pastel
- 1 side of amarillos (ripe, fried plantains)
- 1 order of tostones (green, fried plantains)
- Camarones a la criolla (shrimp in creole sauce)
- Ropa Vieja (shredded beef in tomato base sauce)

This came with side of white rice and black beans (Cuban frijoles) and some bread.  Ok here come to complaints...  The alcapurria, the "dough" tasted unbalance, meaning they used too much of one ingredient (in this case the baby green bananas) and it was overpowering....  They were also oily.  The pastel was ok, certainly lacking the usual kick of flavor I am used to.  Tostones were ok, I make better.  Amarillos are impossible to screw up so these were good.  I have never been a fan of frijoles but these were bland.  The camarones were ok... although the criolla sauce was bleh at best.  Ropa vieja was again ok, nothing to bring me back.  The mamey and pineapple shakes we got were yum though.  Too bad they didn't have guava....  All of thise for around $45.

I might come back and try to aim for when they are busier to see if then the quality of the food improves even if the service is slower as some reviews mention.  All in all, super sweet of them to seat us when they were getting ready to go but the food...  If I spend a little extra time and effort, I can make it better myself....

food - 2 stars
service - 1 star

3 stars at best as of now.
author: melisa n.

description:
Hmmmm....this is a 3.5, really.  

I can't say I am an expert on Puerto Rican food.  So, I'll try keep this light.  

Decor - Eh... pink walls and Puerto Rican maps on the wall aside, they could have done better. 
Appetizers - This was the highlight of our visit: nice, crispy and garlicky tostones and very good pastel (although it is on the small side)
Entree - We shared a chicken dish that came smothered in a really good green salsa/criolla sauce.  It was tasty, but the serving was very small.  The salad was bare - it came with absolutely NO dressing what so ever!  WTF? 
I am sorry but for $10, this entree was on the pricey side. 

After my meal at Nuevo Fruitlandia I dreamt that I was Boricua, a hot Puerto Ricena woman with big boobs and a big butt at that. In my dream I was grinding platano to make pasteles for my adorable Puerto Rican kids (they looked like Max and Emme, JLo and Marc Anthony's kids) waiting at the dinner table (overlooking the clear blue Puerto Rican beach).

And then I woke up....I felt myself up - I am still the short, flat behind Asian chick that I have always been.  Why the weird dream? Maybe it was the tostones....
author: Clarice V.

description: We were leaving Modern Times Bookstore and hungry.  Why not try a Cubana restaurant, eh.  The service was rushed, because unbeknownst to us, they were actually closing when we walked in.  (Oops, next time you should lock your front door.)  So, they allowed us to sit down and eat, but she was whisking away plates and cups to the point of being halfway disrespectful.  We ordered rice and beans, plantains, and a chicken dish with the most delicious green sauce.  I didn't try the plantains, but my dinner companion thought they were cooked just right.  I'd love to go back and try more traditional dishes.  Too bad I'm not a pork eater, because I really want to try the traditional Cuban sandwich.  Oh well, until next time...
author: Felicia P.

description: I lived in Puerto Rico for 35 years and this food is as good as the one I had back home.  The tostones were great, plantain was the right consistency, not to salty, beautiful yellow color, I loved it. I'll be visiting again there soon.
author: Edgardo C.

description:
Soooo...again, I am BORICUA.  I have gone to Fruitilandia several times over the years.  And like the other reviews, I so desperately want to give this place a great rating, BUT i just can't....

The pastellas are homemade and scrumptious.  Just like my great grandmother used to make.  If nothing else, at least try this place for the pastellas, because EVERYONE on this planet would be a happier, better person for having ate a homemade pastellas...

Now....back to the rest of the place... the mofongo is dry and kind of bland, BUT the garlic sauce is tasty.....

But the service is soooooooo slow here....don't go starving, cause you just might start chewing your left arm off while your waiting...

I highly suggest getting appetizers there...because the main dishes are just iffy....

to bad Sofrito in Oakland has closed.   Now THAT is authentic Puerto Rican food....
author: Gretchen F.

description: I've been coming here frequently over the past year because I work nearby and the food is amazing! It's my favorite restaurant on 24th st by a long shot and the small, intimate ambiance is perfect for a date... Or you can just eat at the bar like I do when I'm alone. It's taken me a year to write a review but I'm gonna give it five stars!
author: Shane D.

description:
Okay, so I've only been here once, but it's not my fault. I want to come back, but it seems that every time I wander by, they're closed. What's up with the funky hours?

Anyway, on my one visit, I was delighted by the vegetarian mofongo. Mofongo is a dish I had not tried before and it was fantastic.

The place is cozy and the staff was super friendly despite a bit of language barrier. We ended up saying "thank you" to each other A LOT. Anyway, I'll keep walking by hoping to see if it's ever open again at any point other than while I'm at work.
author: Jere K.

description: I am so pleased to have discovered this place!  The food is so delicious and homey and unpretentious, and the atmosphere is so friendly and charming!  I don't know from authentic, all I know is if it tastes good and is satisfying, and whether it's a good deal for the money, and this place hits high marks for all three.  I have returned several times with friends from South America and Puerto Rico, and each of them gave it high marks, too, and have told me that they have gone back again to introduce it to others.  I have had the roast pork, the shrimp, the picadillo, the chicken, and each of the appetizers and each of the desserts...they are all 100% worth ordering again.  If I had to choose a favorite, I would probably say the pork...it's "oh my god" good.  The sangria is wonderful, too!   I could seriously have dinner here at least once a week.
author: Bumble B.

description:
We heard this place had mofongo, a wonderful mash of plantains, spices and pork that we enjoyed in Puerto Rico several years ago.  And it did, but it wasn't that good.  It was dry and tasteless until we poured some mystery broth over it -- not sure if that was the right thing to do, but it worked.

The picadillo was bland.  The ropa viejo was OK.  The appetizer dumplings, however, were unique + tasty.  Cheap eats.  Not sure it's worth visiting again, though.
author: Rufus X.

description:
One of us is half Puerto Rican but grew up really fond of the food.  The appetizers and the pasteles are really authentic, but the mains are less so.  

For instance what they call Pernil seems more like Spanish food than Puerto Rican.  Real Pernil is usually one of those traditionally poor person cuts of meat such as pork shoulder marinated for about 24 hours and then roasted until it has a crust with some crunch but is still juicy inside.  Something like that would be difficult to make ahead for a restaurant when you have no clue how many people will order it, so compromises end up being made.  At Sofrito in Oakland they leave it roasting all day, whereas at Frutilandia it has been turned into a flattened sauteed pork chop.  It is not bad, but it is not quite right either.

If you want something more authentic go to Sofrito in East Oakland.  If you have been there already and are looking for something better buy a copy of Puerto Rican Cookery by Carmen Aboy Valldejuli (for Puerto Rican food its a cultural institution in the way that Joy of Cooking and Fannie Farmer was for a generation of people here), the instructions are easy to follow although you need to drastically cut the salt if you would like to live past 50.
author: Toy W.

description:
I'm no San Francisco native.  I can count on a hand the times I've been here to do non-touristy stuff.  One day, I was wandering around the city with a good friend of mine, and I decided to give an old friend of mine a call.  She, who is far more familiar with the city, suggested that my friend and I try this place, that it was the best Puerto Ricense/ Cubano food that I'd ever find in a restaurant.  Well, I took her word for it and we went and tried it.

I cannot remember what I had, for it was almost three years ago, and I've only been back once since - but I remember leaving content and not poor both times I went, which is a big deal in my book.

I love Latin American food - the spices, the flavors, the contrasts and the staples.  This is a pretty darn good place.  Very very small, but worth your time.
author: Cody G.

description: Very homey, nice meal, we ordered an appetizer and I ordered the pork dish. I was with a Puerto Rican who grew up with the kind of food they serve, it made an experience a whole lot different! I understood most of their conversation in Spanish when they talked about food! It's an universal topic!!
author: Yoko S.

description:
So we decided to try this place on a whim one early evening to get some dinner on our vacation.  It was about 4pm and the restaurant was all but empty: we thought perhaps it was just a downtime before the dinner rush.  Now we know that maybe there was something else to it!

The food wasn't bad, but it was really nothing special.

But what disappointed me the most was the complete and total lack of service by the one waitress in the restaurant.  I think she visited our table a total of 3 times.  Once to take our order, once to bring the food, and once to take our money!  I'm not even sure she refilled our water glasses during our meal.  What really got me was that even when I asked for assistance, it was hard to get any attention.  Mind you, there was only one other couple in the restaurant at this point.  I needed silverware, and because the waitress was so busy playing with her phone, I needed to get up to get her attention. So I got up, walked to the other side of the restaurant to ask for silverware.  Rather than just hand me some, she directed me to the metal cup on the table which was supposed to have silverware in it.  Well, since ours didn't, when I returned to the table I had to get up again to hunt down a fork from another table.  After checking the three tables immediately around us and finding only butter knives, I had to walk again to the back of the restaurant to take from another table.  Oh yeah, and then I had to do that whole process again to get napkins....

I wouldn't have minded as much, but there was nothing else going on in the restaurant at that time.  The waitress wasn't prepping, cleaning, organizing, refilling the empty silverware and napkins on other tables....she was playing with her cell phone the entire time.

As I said above the food wasn't anything special, so I can't even say there was a saving grace for our whole experience.  In that neighborhood, you can eat at any number of places with similar food, and almost certainly better service.
author: E S.

description:
It's not Cuban food, I'm not sure exactly what it is but it's definitely not Cuban. I realize that I'm not in Little Havana or Spanish Harlem, I get that, but having Cuban food on the menu doesn't make you a Cuban restaurant. I think the owners are actually Nica's or something, but they're not legit. If Wang Foo's Chinese restaurant served spaghetti and meatballs could they be classified as an Italian restaurant? The bistec palomilla was way off, the chicken soup is some kind of Mexican/ Peruvian hybrid, and the black beans were straight out of a can. Also, when you order papas fritas from a legit Cuban spot, you get thin fries that then get thrown onto the steak and get taken down in one fowl swoop, not some steak fries with old bay seasoning that have to be ordered separately. 
I gave an extra star for the effort, because this is after all San Francisco and no one knows good Cuban food around here.
author: mario p.

description:
I came here on a date today, being that my date was Puertorican I let his ass do the ordering.  This location definitely has that hole in the wall vibe. Being that my mom grew up in the Caribbean, this type of food was not too foreign to me.

It appeared that only one lady was running the entire show there, so good thing we came at a non-busy time.   I requested to try the mango shake, and ordered their Sunday pork special.  My date also got an assortment of the appetizers but please don't expect me to remember the names cuz I'm Americanized like that!  My favorite was the smashed up plantain fried with the garlic dipping sauce on the side.. delish!

Either way, everything was really good, although I'm docking a point for finding part of a plastic something in my shake, which I could have choked on had I attempted to swallow it! 

The main meal was ok, the pork itself was a little on the dry side, but I found dunking in it that garlic oil stuff to do wonders.  The yucca was yummy and so was the bean rice combo stuff.

I'm not sure if I would make the the trek out here on my own to come back, but if I have a Spanish speaker as my escort I'd definitely be game again!
author: Jaime P.

description:
Definitely coming back and trying more menu items!

Mofongo -- HELL YES!  So good.  
Chicken Soup -- yummy, yummy, if I were sick, I would want this.
Pierna de Puerco Horneada -- so tender, delicious green marinade...
Ropa Vieja -- deliciously flavored, my friend loved it.

Loved hearing someone chopping something all to hell in the back.  

Closed on Mondays and no special on Wednesday...

Yes, service is slow but this is an island restaurant...also they were out of several of the beers, but again this feels *authentic* to me.  And can someone please.  Please.  PLEASE direct me to a location where I can get a can of Medalla Light?  I drank that stuff like water in PR.
author: Dwayne A.

description:
FOOD 4.5 stars

Service and Bathroom -  2 stars

You know those little local restaurants you find on hidden away streets when you are on vacation?  You know, the ones that are amazing one night, but may be just OK on another night?   The ones with seating for less than 20 people?  The ones where you know the menu doesn't change much because they like what they make and it usually tastes great.  Then ones where you go to use the bathroom and you think about donating enough money for them to replace the disgusting mini-blinds that are so bad they make you throw up a little bit in your own mouth?  (ok, perhaps too much info)

Well this is one of those places.  I have the picadillo a la viejo and a hot and crispy order of the tostones.    The tostones came to my table reeking of garlic and too hot to eat  --- PERFECT.

The main dish was like something I would get at a Cuban friends house (except that the rise was just OK).  The flavors were great, the portion was a good size.  

I will be back soon.
author: Dan W.

description: Used an AmazonLocal deal of $12 for $24 worth of food. Ended up spending $18 all together (with tip). TERRIBLE FOOD AND OVERPRICED. I ordered the appetizer combo without the alcapurria (since I'm pescatarian) and extra tostones instead. The tostones were hard, over-fried and tasteless. The maduros was okay but a little over-fried as well. The yucca was okay. I then ordered the baked empanada with spinach, ricota cheese, and onions since they were out of the cheese, tomato and basil one. They come pre-made apparently. It came out looking like cafeteria food. The empanada was smallish and hard, almost like it just came out of the microwave. I've had better hot pockets than this!! It was served with a small plastic bowl of flavorless black beans and a side of rice. I didn't even get the cilantro chutney with it but it's my fault for not reminding the waitress. It also came with a salad that was very skimp on the dressing. Overall, very overpriced for the crap they serve on a plate. Can't remember a worse meal I've had in the city, literally. It was my first time having Puerto Rican food, maybe I'm just not a fan but this was almost insulting. On top of everything, the fried plantains mixed with the microwaved empanada and black beans made my stomach toss and turn a little afterwards. Very unsatisfied and will never go back to this hole in the wall. The server was very sweet though so I give it a star.
author: Macaulay H.

description: IF you LOVE garlic and LOVE plantain ... you have got to try the MOFONGO at this place! The first time I ever tried PR food was here --- at Fruitilandia ... that was about 3 years ago ... BOY ... when I took my first bite of that MOFONGO ... OMG! so much going on in my mouth ... flavor bud wise ~~  I've yet to have better mofongo ... the other stuff on the menu is good ~ nothing FANTABULOUS ... but the MONFONGO is indescribably delicious!!!  Overall~I would def. recommend!!
author: Bravo J.

description: I have been here a few times, and im always satisfied.  my cuban and puerto rican coworkers swear by it as authentic, and authentic or not, i know good food when i taste it.  not to mention, its easy on the wallet.  good lunch specials too, sandwiches are yummy.  other good stuff includes, ropa vieja, baca frita, mofongo, pollo en salsa verde, those are the ones i have tried, and will try some more stuff when i go back.  the little tamal-like pasteles are yummy too.
author: Charlie M.

description: The food was ok.  I tried the ropa vieja, very small amount of meat and very oily.  I also tried couple of appetizers and the oil seem burned.  I wont' come back
author: Veronica M.

description:
Great food for a reasonable price.  

I left there so full and reminded me of my trip down to Puerto Rico and all the good times.

Love the warm bread and they play great tunes...Have you heard a Bryan Adams song in Spanish?  If not, go here...
author: Dan D.

description: I've been dining here since before I could crawl and I still frequent this little authentic Latin restaurant in the Mission. I love it, I'm half Cuban, and this place reminds me of abuelas home cooking. It's the real deal and is the closest thing you're gonna get to authentic Latin food in the Bay Area.
author: Diego C.

description: horrible service. took forever to get a seat and they took so long to take a drink order that we walked out.  it wasn't that busy either, they just do not aim to please
author: Alejandro S.

description:
I walked in excited.

I walked out (after eating) feeling eh.

Nothin to write home about.

Mom cooks way better.

Been there; done that.
author: Sergio R.

description: my boyfriends dad got a group on deal for this resturaunt and we planned to go for months just yesterday a day before the coupon expired we went down to have a good meal together. I enjoyed the place i think it would be advised to come earlier because twoards 7 or 8 the more complicated dishes arent being served. it was quite small but frisco is famous for having small diners with some of the most amazing food. i got the alcapurria and it was delicious if only it was TRIPPLE the size but it was a great appetizer maybe order 3 or 4 to start you off i only got one and loved it! I would say the service was a bit slow but they were very friendly and tried to accomadate all our needs and they were quite busy before closing. I also wish they had photos on thier menu because im not familiar with all the dishes they served but they all sounded amazing i think i could have picked something even more delicous for my entree if i was able to see more photographs of the dishes. Other than that our deal came with 4 sangrias for all 4 of us who attended and it was mixed just right. I think overall if your ever feeling a little lazy to cook some puerto rican food and you want to get out of the house why not stop in. i will visit this place again some day soon. give it a try.
author: Saranaz S.

description: so where do i start....1# the salsa music playing gave it a latin welcome vibe..2# had the mofongo and that was good but not good!..3# i had a sangria and that was bla!!..4# i had the ropa vieja with puertorican rice and lets just say i wish i rather had gone to the taco truck instead..5# if i was running the place i make it a priority that when the guest are done to make sure the waiters remove the plates before bringing out the bill..6#bottom line only reason i go bk is if i was walking near by and had to use the bathroom other then that this place let me down...but ill let u make ur own call..
author: Ivan C.

description: The Bay Area has real Cuban food!!!  Who knew?  I spent a summer living in Miami, and ever since then, I've been craving authentic Cuban food, and I've finally found it here at Frutilandia!    It's a hole in the wall in a semi-sketchy part of the Mission, and we were the only people when we went for lunch around 1 pm, so we were kind of scared that the food was going to be terrible, but it was fantastic.   Order the tostones and the bistec empanizado (my favorite Cuban dish).   Skip the papa rellena.
author: A M.

description: We started on a promising note at these cute renovated spot, however by the end, we were extremely disappointed in the service and food.  We arrived in the thick of the Dia De Los Muertos procession on 24th St. and were promised a table for 4 within 15 minutes, which was accomplished.  The waitperson was very sweet and accommodating.  However, once we placed our orders, they forgot to bring our eating utencils, plates and napkins, they forgot our salads which were included with the entree, and the food either came out lukewarm or later than the other entrees.  When I informed the waitperson that they forgot to serve our salads, he apologized, but didn't offer anything else to compensate.  He could have comped our dessert and coffee, or given us more sangria, but nothing.  I think they were too overwhelmed by the crowds, but Customer Service 101 basics would suggest you do something to make up for a mistake with the customer.  Needless to say, I'll go somewhere else on 24th St. as there are plenty of other options.
author: Julia H.

description: I was so happy when I finally found this place.  You can almost miss it because the sign is so small.  I am half Cuban and half Puerto Rican.  I thought I had to wait till I went to NY to visit relatives so I could have pasteles.  They had them here and the waitress told me they have them every day (not just on special occasions).  The soup actually bought tears to my husbands eyes.  He said it tasted exactly like my mothers.  I was not having soup, I was there for the pasteles.  I took a dozen home with me.
author: Molly B.

description: i'm hoping people can give this place 5 stars from now on because they truly deserve it , other than the service is super fast  the food is extremly hearty and homemade, big portions and a great prices, i think they remodeled it looks neat and very cozy , bring their stars up people they deserve it,  we had a great chicken cilantro stew and shredded streak with creole sauce , amazing :)
author: NAEL K.

description: Bland beyond belief, flat tasting and simple. I have found that the only Latin American food I'll ever eat is Mexican.
author: .James A.

description:
With every passing year, I think my metabolism slows down another critical increment.  And so, no way was there going to be a ridiculous MEATFEST for my bday this time!  We loaded up instead on plaintains at El Nuevo Frutilandia, in the form of their Aperitivos Surtidos and Mofongo.  I'm not sure which item was what, but the tamale looking thing on the combo dish was great, and the Mofongo (it was like hash) was REALLY good with the accompanying tomato-ey/brothy sauce.
Okay - we are talking about MY bday - so there was plenty of protein coming thru the kitchen.  The Fried Pork Chops were AWESOME, just like grandma used to make.  Yes, my grandma is Chinese, but nevertheless, it was JUST like how she used to fry it up - simple salt and pepper yumminess. I got the Picadillo a La Habana Vieja - which I enjoyed - can't go wrong with ground beef, tomato sauce and pimiento olives. I also got a bite of their Ropa Vieja - which was just ok to me; I mean it was moist and flavorful, but over-hyped to me.
I wish I could say how the dishes my other companions tried were, but they ate it all :-\
In conclusion, it was classic home-cooking w/Puerto Rican spices.  I could probably make a lot of the stuff myself, but being the lazy fuck that I am, I'll pay the very reasonable prices to have El Nuevo do it for me.  Just be forewarned they take that treat-you-like-family-thing to heart: they'll take their time, you gotta bug the waitress for what you want, but she's gonna give you a big ol' kiss and hug if it's your bday.

As I get older...but not really wiser...that worked out just right.  Having some good food, and spending time with people (some I see everyday, and some I don't get to see enough of) who warm my otherwise dead insides....there was no better way to spend my bday.

*WTF with the happy sappy shit? Finds a little kid to push down*
author: CINDY K.

description: I'm so glad I discovered this hidden gem! I'm not at all familiar with Cuban or Puerto Rican food, so this is a nice place for me to branch out. Everything I've ordered has been delicious. Great service, too (the waitress is awesome!).
author: Joyce G.

description: I'm not a real fan of this place but hey, if  I gotta get my fix of Cuban food way out west from Miami where I'm from, this is about as close as can get.  The casual family style ambience does take me back to those Miami restaurants you walk into with the plastic placemats, a cold glass of ice water, and a basket full of  hot buttered Cuban bread.  OK, Fruitilandia is not quite that.  Nothing here approximates what real Cuban bread is like.  The food is OK which is another reason I rate it 3 stars but for being Cuban food, the portions are small.
author: David R.

description: I'm sticking with 2 stars on this one. The mofongo is growing on me and is quite tasty but it's not enough to outweigh the slow service and other mediocre food. This recent visit I had plantains, beans, and rice. The beans were surprisingly disappointing. Who screws up beans? They were watery and bland. The plantains were just okay, too. Much prefer the plantains at Bissap Baobab or ChaChaCha.
author: Susan L.

description: The skrimps were absolutely fresh and delicious in a slightly-spicy red sauce. The plantains were crispy, salty, and sweet. For some reason, I thought this place was Cuban, but no worries. I'll be back the next time the mood strikes.
author: Jess F.

description: I'm always surprised SF doesn't have more Cuban restaurants.  This place is AMAZING and we'll definitely be back. Great Cuban and food and we felt like we were back in Miami.  My husband and I went and had a huge spread for only $30 - great value for your money.  The staff was also incredibly nice.
author: M P.

description:
I had such high hopes for this place. Since it's the only Puerto Rican restaurant in SF (that anyone can find) I really wanted to give it as much praise as I possibly could.  

Unfortunately, I'd have to rate the food at Fruitilandia as so-so at best.  I  started with the Mofongo, which had a delicious garlic sauce but I couldnt taste any of the bits of pork, and the large pieces of fried tostones nearly chipped my teeth.  My sis had the Yuca Con Mojo (yucca with garlic).  She really loved that dish and I thought it had a great flavor but the yucca is way to rich for me.  My little nephew had the french fries, which were the best fries I've ever had anywhere, yummy!  Next, I tried the fried pork chops with rice and black beans.  Again, flavor was fabulous but the chops were fried to a crisp.  Sis had the Camarones Al Ajillo, Shrimp with Garlic.  The only problem with this dish was that it should've been described as shrimp with wine sauce because the wine was soooo overpowering, that was all we could taste.  The mango juice was refreshing and the chicken soup was good.  I am willing to give this place a 2nd chance, if someone on yelp can recommend a few of the outstanding dishes to try out.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I've had a lot of Cuban and Puerto Rican food in New York and there was something missing to the point that I didn't recognize the food as either Cuban nor Puerto Rican.  There was no WOW factor to any of the dishes.  I had the Chile Verde Chicken and my guest had the steak.  The chicken dish was boring and the portion of black beans would have been size appropriate for a four year old.  The chicken dish and the overall flavors reminded me of a El Salvadorean restaurant closer to Valencia St.

My guest liked her steak but thought the food was bland.  We looked around and we couldn't figure out why the restaurant was full and we decided that the Americans liked it because it was bland.  Nothing picante here in a neighborhood full of picante restaurants. 

Back to the Cuban restaurants in New York.  I never saw just plain white rice served.  The rice always had tomato, or zafron or cooked with chicken broth that gave it real flavor.   If you want an authentice Cuban or Puerto Rican restaurant, this isn't it.  If you want someone's idea of Cuban or Puerto Rican food that has nothing spicy and you have hours to wait for your food and anything else you order, this place is for you.     

Service was horrible.  The waitress never brought our coffee and gave us butter but the bread never arrived.  We waited 10 minutes before the bill arrived and this is a small restaurant.
author: Todd T.

description: This place really needs to get it together.  I'm all about the chill laid-back latin american ambiance and vibe but it seems like the people who run this restaurant are more concerned about socializing with each other, playing on their android phones and babysitting their kids than taking care of their customers.  The food was mediocre at best. Was that boil bag rice they served me? The meat appeared to be roasted but was served in an odd shredded manner unlike any meat I've ever been served in a cuban restaurant (usually it comes out in one whole piece- like a roast or a skirt steak).  I wasn't asked if I wanted another sangria until I was signing the check and on my way out the door. I was served my dinner without cutlery and had to ask for a fork. the next day on Thursday when I walked past the place, the management had a sign advertising the food special that was offered the day before still on the sign (and the sign read, "Wednesday"). The people were kind of friendly (although much more so right as I was signing the check/tipping) and seemed nice but overall it was just an overpriced, mediocre experience.
author: Shane H.

description: Wow!!!  I will fly in from LA for their authentic Puerto Rican food.  I felt like I was home.....on the island of Puerto Rico.  The slow service is worth the wait, because I know they are cooking from scratch not frozen.  The best alcapuria I have had in years!  Carne gizada, with white rice and pink beans, mmmmmm....delicious.  Tamarindo drink perfect, not to sweet, not to tart.  Can't wait to fly into SF this weekend.
author: yolanda g.

description: This place is amazing. The food is made to order, it takes a while but is very worth the wait. Order the soup it is very tasty and so are the mofongo and tostones. I ordered the milanesa plate and was very pleased. We come here every time we are in town.
author: Jackie J.

description:
I have to start off by saying that I never write reviews because I just have way too many other things to do. However, I have to write about Frutilandia because I am a Puerto Rican woman who grew up in Spanish-Harlem and spent many childhood summers in Puerto Rico. I cook Puerto Rican food, my family cooks Puerto Rican food, I love Puerto Rican food, I love to promote Puerto Rican food because I like to spread love and happiness.

However, Frutilandia DOES NOT cook authentic Puerto Rican dishes. I read some reviews from some other "Puerto Ricans" who stated that Frutilandia is authentic. They lie. A real Puerto Rican, or even someone who has simply spent time in a Puerto Rican community will tell you that this is not Puerto Rican food. Some of the food may look authentic but isn't. This upsets me because I don't want people to think that this is how our food tastes. Puerto Rican food is just such a beautiful thing and I don't want it to get a bad rep because of Frutilandia. 

Now on a positive note the staff is very warm and friendly. I feel kind of sorry for them. The food is just soooo bad. 

If you want to get an idea of how Puerto Rican food is supposed to be prepared, take a trip out to San Rafael and check out Sol Food. I've never eaten there but a friend of mine who was born and raised in Puerto Rico always brings me food from there and it is gooood, and he said the owners are from Puerto Rico.
author: Yvette L.

description: The place was cozy, the lady was nice- she even let me cancel the mango shake which I originally ordered but then decided to slurp some of my friends instead. I ordered the fried plantains, YUMMY, Mofongo, Yummy, but the Beef shredded dish was a bit disappointing, a bit dry and not so tasty.. I had to hot sauce everything. But since it was hanging with friends, the place was nice and quiet!! we came at like noon, no one was there.. but it was a random Wednesday for lunch .
author: Tulie L.

description:
tasty little cuban/puerto rican restaurant in the mission.
their agua frescas were pretty good.  i can't remember the name of the one i had though.  some exotic fruit :)
i had some pork chops for dinner which were tasty, but not anything extraordinary from alot of latin restaurants.
the service was friendly and the restaurant was pretty quiet since there were only about 3 or 4 other diners while i was there.
author: charlotte s.

description: Really disappointing experience. Restaurant was empty apart from one table and that should be enough information right there. They were out of their special of the day (bacalao), but since it was a weekday and the restaurant was pretty much empty, I found this very hard to believe (read: they never made the special of the day). The vaca frita I ordered instead was small and much tougher than meat that simmers for so long should be. We waited about 45 mins. after ordering. The chicken soup was very bland as well. Our waitress was very unfriendly. My friend had some yucca that did seem pretty good. I will not return though - worst Cuban experience yet.
author: Alexander G.

description: I had a friend visiting from Puerto Rico. He wanted to sample local Puerto Rican fair. This was all I was able to find. So off we went. With the exception of the Mofongo, which was really tasty, I thought the food was pretty bland, but not bad. When I think Latin I want spice. I want heat. There was none of that. Just simple Puerto Rican and Cuban comfort food.
author: Kent T.

description: The food is delicious and the service is still the same.  It might take a while for your food to arrive and you might be half done with your fruit shake, but once you hear those pounding foot steps getting closer, that means that you're foods comin'.  I love the bistec, and savoring the traces of garlic, the black beans, tostones, yucca frita, sandwich suisso (toasted bread with ham and swiss cheese, not a lot of ingredients, but damn tasty,) and the fruit shakes.  On the walls you can see that Marc Anthony and Jennifer Lopez have already eaten there. Not much has changed from the time I was a six to now, except they added "Nuevo" to its name.
author: Glu C.

description: This place has AWESOME Cuban and Puerto Rican food.  Ever since I moved out here from Florida, I've been missing good Cuban food and I finally found it!  I had the mixed appetizer platter, which was HUGE and delicious, and the Vaca Frita, which was so good it much be a sin.  Only reason I can't give 5 stars is because there was only 1 person working the WHOLE restaurant while we were there, so service was slow, and she didn't really speak English so I ended up with red wine when I ordered white.  Otherwise, though, an excellent restaurant and I'll definitely be returning!
author: Liz P.

description: Puerto Rican here.  Great place. The Vaca Frita (although Cuban) is by far my favorite plate. You HAVE to try it!.  Also try the Yuca al Mojo, mmm.
author: Noel S.

description: Good cuban sandwiches.  Pierna de puerco is also a good one.  The Sunday night special is tasty.  The owner is very friendly and helpful.
author: Al K.

description: Don't come to Frutilandia if you are in a hurry - it's a slow experience, only 2 people were working when we visited.  I'm no expert on Puerto Rican food, but we enjoyed it.  We went heavy on apps and will go back to try the entrees.
author: Kelli R.

description: I'm all about their appetizers. Unfortunately I'm not too crazy about their entrees. A bit on the bland side but the cozy atmosphere makes up for it. If you're not spanish this is probably a good place for you, since spicy is a hit and miss for you folks.
author: Diana C.

description: The service was the worst I have ever had...the server was the waitress, cook, bus person, dish washer all in one!  No one there to help her...the food is so bad...unbelievably bad, just awful.  The Coco Rico was warm, the Alcapurria, she cook it three times, thinking that she had it right.  The first time cooked, she burnt it, the second time is was raw and the third time it was over cooked to a crisp.  The owner/cook is from El Salvador not Puerto Rican...!  If there was a half a star I would have given it that!
author: Dianne L.

description: Used to come here as a kid and loved it, need to make it a point to get back....mmmm...Coco Rico
author: John D.

description: I went to this place with a couple of friends for a birthday celebration, and I really enjoyed it. The Mofongo was delicious! I ordered the Bistek de Palomilla which was a bit lemony for me. It was still good, but having only tasted a few different versions, I could not say if it was more or less authentic than the other. I will definitely return to this place as I want to try the ropa vieja and other entrees. My friends had the vaca frita and a pork dish The pork was a bit dry, but I also enjoyed the vaca frita. The Mofongo though was the hit for me!
author: Berna P.

description: Good basic ethnic comfort food. Go there for a leisurely dinner with someone that you can enjoy a good conversation with. The chicken soup, plantains and pastellas are wonderful.
author: Chris R.

description: I also really wanted to like this place.  I've always been curious when I've walked down 24th St.  A couple friends and I went in. I knew something was off because while there were lots of tables open, only 2 were clean.  Ah well, perhaps their busboy was sick that day.  It seemed there were only two people working, the cook and the waitress.  The waitress must have been stressed out.  When she finally got around to taking our order, it was rushed and she was too busy to even ask what we'd like to drink. I felt like we were just stressing her out by being there. The food got there. It was good enough, but not great.  What was worse was the stomach ache I got about an hour after.  Something just wasn't right.  What a shame.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Amazing!!  My mom was cuban and my dad was Puerto Rican so I was raised on delicious cuban/puerto rican food!  We recently moved to the area and I have been craving a taste of home.   We found our corner of Miami here in San Francisco!  Everything we ate was FANTASTIC!  My favorite dish is Vaca Frita and it was made exceptionally well here!  Make sure to get black beans and rice and some yuca - delicious!!  The mofongo (you are supposed to eat it with the broth!) as an appetizer was FANTASTIC!  And if you have room make sure to get a cafe con leche and some flan to end your meal just right!

It's a dive but well worth the trip and cheap!   We will be back often I am sure!  One note - they are closed on Mondays.
author: Ted D.

description: i love this place.  i used to go there at least once a week but then i had to get a grip and cut back.  the chile rellenos are AMAZING.  i do love all of the vegetarian dishes but the chile rellenos are to be savored - i have actually contemplated asking them to teach me how to make them.  it can take a while to get your food but that's part of the charm.  the fruit shakes are sort of like milkshakes but not nearly as sweet - i recommend pineapple or mango.  oh, and everyone i have taken there who eats meat swears by the chicken soup.
author: Kristie P.

description: The greatest crime committed here against Cuban gastrocentricity es el cafe Cubano.  Just skip that menu item altogether.  At best Frutilandia is ok, other times it is as if the head chef is on vacation and they gave a handful of recipes to the guy at the taqueria down the street who has never even eaten Cuban food.  Speaking from the perspective of a Cuban raised in Miami, this place is disappointingly the most authentic Cuban/Puerto Rican restaurant in SF.  I keep going back because I don't always want to have to cook everything myself, but each time I leave more and more disheartened.  Good Cuban food, like good Cuban people, should give everyone hugs and kisses, but Frutilandia is a cold, weak handshake sin gusto.
author: Q Q.

description: i,m not gonna even say i,m an expert on puerto rican cuisine but i have been here quite a few times and the food is preatty good not the best but good i really like there tostones i also had the puerto rican pasteles and alcapurrias and they where on hit i once had a spacial it was lechon with arroz con gandules they also sell some cuban dishes they sell good ropa vieja and there vaca frita is hella good i also had a cuban sandwhich it was on hit i met quite a few boricuas in the bay area hopefully one day one of them will open up a new puerto rican restaurant in san fran one day it,s long over due but for right now if you find your self in the city this is the only place that i know of that sells puerto rican food  on a last note the staff is very freindly....
author: Jose C.

description: we got lunch from this restaurant and it was good!  i really liked the fried plantain (spell?).  i would go there just for that again.
author: Hiromi M.

description: Ate here for the first time the other night. We had the mofongo appetizer - yummy but a little on the heavy side; the ceviche - great flavor, lots of fish and hot peppers; and the special, which was a roasted pork dish called Lechon Horneado. That was the bomb. Melt in your mouth succulent. Amazing flavor that easily rivaled a cubano pork dish I had in Little Havana. And the meat was also extremely lean. I didn't see a speck of fat. Service was a little slow. Good prices, lots of food. I'd go back and try other things on the menu.
author: Lisa M.

description: this place isn't strictly puerto rican, it's cuban too.  the best cuban food i've found in the bay area is in san jose - a place called la havana.  but frutilandia is in my neighborhood and doesn't require getting on the highway.  nice soup.  nice bread.  nothing amazing but it's solid neighborhood grub and very friendly service.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Relaxing Sunday lunch with a friend.  The 2 of us shared an order of  pork chops (2 decent size and succulent pieces).  The chops were accompanied by black beans, rice and choice of soup/salad.  We also ordered a side of plantanos maduros (sweet plaintains) which is my idea of heaven on earth in a 3 x 2 dish. An extra bowl of black bean soup which was oh so lovely and shared the fresh batido de fresa (strawberry milk shake).  Get this--the tab was $21 total.  Worth looking for parking for 10 minutes or so.  I've dined at this restaurant at least a dozen times in the past 10 years and this was the best meal ever!
author: marsh m.

description: This is the best Puerto Rican food in the bay area. The food is excellent, the service is personal and the prices are amazing. I come here every chance a get - always a special treat!
author: Rich C.

description: 3.5 The arroz con pollo was fantastic! The mofongo was good. Cool spot...kinda slow service, but not super expensive either. Biggest disappointment: they gave us styrofoam boxes.
author: Cassie C.

description: My wife really likes Cuban and Puerto Rican food and so we tried out this restaurant.  (I prefer spicier fare, e.g. Mexican or Jamaican).  We went on a Sat. nite and the restaurant had only a few customers.  Which is too bad because the food was good, the prices reasonable, and the service efficient.  I had the Ropa Vieja and added lots of hot sauce--the server seemed a bit insulted.  My wife had the Mofongo and enjoyed it.  Not being an expert on this kind of food--nor ever wanting to gain an expertise on it--I defer to the other critics on this page.  But it was a pleasant experience, especially for my wife.
author: Murray S.
